Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have completed this book for you, my Sons, which is the last in the science of medicine with its completion, and I have reached the end in it through its explanations and clarifications, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise, which is part of the practice, namely surgery, by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since the practice of surgery has been neglected in our region and time, entirely deprived such that perhaps the knowledge of it perished and its traces were cut off; and there remained from it only brief descriptions in ancient books, which hands have altered: errors and hesitations befell them until their intentions were closed and their vision diminished. It seemed to me that I should revive it with the order of this Treatise according to the way of positioning, explanation, and abbreviation: and to bring forth forms of cautery tools and other instruments of the work, as they are produced by adding explanations and preparing what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why a good practitioner of it with their hands is not found in this time of ours is: because the art of medicine is long, and its author must be trained before that in the science of anatomy as narrated by Galen, until they know the aids to members, and their forms, and their conjunction and separation, and have knowledge of bones, nerves, muscles, and their numbers, and their emergence, and pulsating veins, and quiet veins, and places of exit for them.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for this reason, Hippocrates said that knowing the name of something is much, but knowing how to work with it is little, especially in the art of hands.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already said this at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since those who are not knowledgeable about what we have said regarding anatomy do not escape falling into error by which people are killed: just as I saw many of those who claim to be formed in this science and boast about it without knowledge and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What happened was that I saw a foolish doctor cut into a scrofulous abscess on the neck of a woman, and he cut some arteries in her neck: therefore, the woman bled until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another doctor who took it upon himself to extract a stone from a man who had become advanced in age, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He therefore proceeded to do so and extracted it along with part of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore, the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I had indeed been called to extract it: and upon seeing the size of the stone and the condition of the patient, I saw that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another doctor who was receiving payment from one of our country's dukes for his medical services: and it happened to a black eunuch in his service that he suffered a fracture near the heel: and the doctor, with his ignorance, hurried and bound the fracture above the wound with bandages and tight bindings, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he dismissed him according to his own wishes.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	After that, he left him for several days and instructed him not to loosen the bandage: and he stood like this until his leg became ulcerated, and his foot as well, and he ended up in a state of ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was therefore called to him: and I hurried to loosen the ligature: and peace followed, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the corruption was already established in the member: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore, the corruption ceased to spread in the member until it was destroyed.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another doctor who punctured a cancerous abscess: and it ulcerated for days until the evil of it increased with his lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	Which means that when there is a pure cancer caused by black bile, then it is not necessary to approach it with iron at all, unless it is in a member that can tolerate having the entire part removed.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for that reason, my children, it is necessary for you to know that the practice with the hand is divided into two divisions: namely, an operation which is associated with healing; and an operation which involves danger in many circumstances.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already noted throughout this book wherever there comes an operation involving fear and danger.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore, it is necessary for you to be cautious about that and avoid it: so that the foolish do not find a way to speak and disgrace it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, take the measure with care and protection, and treat your patients with ease and firmness, and use a better way leading by God's grace to health and commendable succession: and leave behind severe illnesses difficult to heal: and remove from yourselves that which causes fear, so that hesitation does not enter into your faith and benefit.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it remains more for your glory, and is higher in this world, and finally for your rewards.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat illness badly; do not be called bad doctors.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	About cauterization with fire and cauterization with sharp medicine, arranged and ordered from head to foot, and the forms of instruments and tools used for cauterization: and everything that is necessary for the procedure.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	About incision and puncture, bloodletting and ventosity, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows, and similar procedures: and all arranged in chapters with forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	About restoration, dislocation, and treatment of sprains, and similar procedures: arranged in chapters from head to foot, and with forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory to God Alone.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	About the Benefit and Harm of Cauterization: and which constitutions it is suitable for, and at what time: and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before I recall the procedure with him, it is necessary for me to say what are his aids and disadvantages, and in which temperament they are exhibited.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say then, that the discourse on the quality of the aid of cauterization and its disadvantage is a lengthy and subtle discourse, a science and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Moreover, many wise people have spoken about it, and they have disagreed on the matter. For my part, a little of their discourses is sufficient for me, fearing to prolong [the discussion].
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say then, that cauterization benefits universally all temperaments, both those with material and without material, except for two temperaments, which are the hot temperament without material and the dry temperament without material.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, in the hot and dry temperament with material, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some have said that cauterization is beneficial in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite, namely that cauterization is not suitable for a disease caused by heat and dryness: for the nature of fire is heat; it is inappropriate to treat with heat and dryness when the condition arises from heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite states that cauterization provides relief in every disease caused by heat and dryness that occurs in human bodies: for when you compare the body of a person and its moisture to the nature of fire, you find the human body to be cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I say through his speech: because from experience it has already revealed this to me on several occasions.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it is not appropriate for someone to come upon this unless they have already been tested and trained in the final chapter of the Cauterization Exercise, and have knowledge of the diversity of human constitutions, and the disposition of illnesses within them, and their causes, and their accidents, and the duration of time involved.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	However, there is no need for fear from the remaining constitutions: especially in cold and humid illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	Now all the doctors have agreed on them: and they do not disagree about helping with Cauterization in these cases.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, my children, that from the secret of treatment with Cauterization using fire, and its goodness when combined with burning medicine is clear: for fire is simple, whose action does not reach beyond the member being cauterized: and it does not harm another connected member, except with slight injury.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of burning medicine, however, reaches what is distant from the limbs: and it may cause illness that is difficult to cure in a member, and perhaps even lead to death.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not cause harm unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Now it has become clear to us through experience, due to the length of service and study with the art, and standing upon the truth of things: and for this reason I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not the case that it is not allowed for this book of mine, I would bring to you a secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation on bodies by expelling them, which demonstrates through philosophical speech how it expels illnesses, though it might sharpen your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, children, that they disagree on the time when it should be done to cauterize, and they place a better time for the true one.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cauterization is appropriate at all times: therefore, because the harm caused by the time is submerged in the healing that is drawn with the cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cauterization is for pains caused by necessary, severe, and urgent conditions that do not tolerate delay: therefore, because it is feared that from them a greater harm may occur than the minor damage incurred due to waiting for the right time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let it not enter your minds, children, that which is not considered except by the masses and foolish doctors, namely that to the illness which is cured by cauterization there is never a relapse: and they place this as a consequence, but the matter is not as they think: because cauterization is nothing other than in place of medicine that alters the constitution and dries up the humidities which are the cause of why pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cauterization is unnecessary when it surpasses medicine in the speed of recovery and the power of its operation and the strength of its authority: and it is possible for illness to return at some hour of time according to the patient's constitution, and the location of his illness, and its power: and what is prepared in his body through the aggregation of excesses within him: and what reaches him in acquisition from food, and similar causes, unless the illness occurs in which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	An illness that is subtle in a member with few excesses and humidities, such as the cauterization of a tooth due to pain and similar cases, it is possible for that pain not to return.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that is done in a few [steps].
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	However, the talk of the common people again, that cautery is the last resort of medicine, is correct speech; not as they themselves intend in it: for they believe that there is no treatment which compares with medicine, nor with anything else after the setting aside of cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The matter is actually the opposite of what they say, and the intent that cautery is the last resort of medicine is only this: when we administer methods of treatment for certain illnesses, and those treatments do not help; then at the end we administer cautery, which does prove effective. Thus it falls out that cautery is the last of medicine, but not according to the understanding intended by the common people and many foolish doctors.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron: and they did not say this except because of the equality and superiority of gold's substance: and they said that the place where cautery is applied does not produce pus.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	Yet this is not true absolutely: for I have now tested it and found that it does not hold true in certain bodies without other factors.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cautery with gold is good and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you heat gold for cautery in fire, it does not become clear to you how much heat is sufficient because of the redness of gold: and when it quickly reaches a certain coolness, if you add more heat to it, it melts in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the craftsman falls into confusion with that: and because of this, cautery with iron is quicker and more convenient for us, being straightforward in its application.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I indeed have already arranged this chapter on Cauterization according to the chapters: and I have arranged them from head to foot, so that whoever seeks it may find what they want from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	¶ On the method of cauterizing the head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here cauterization is applied to the domain of humidity and coldness above the brain: there are two causes of soda formation, and an abundance of fluid flow from the head to the parts around the eyes and ears, and an abundance of dreaming, and pain in the teeth, and throat pain: and generally all illnesses that arise from coldness, such as paralysis, soda formation, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar conditions.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is that you instruct the patient to first evacuate with dissolving and cleansing medicine for three nights or four, depending on the strength of the patient, their age, and their habits.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then have him sit between your hands in a square position, so that he places his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that place with a cautery.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then heat the olive-shaped cauterization tool: this is its form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the marked spot with a cautery, and as your hand is gradually drawn down, you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly move your hand, and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that the quantity of the head of Alkaiel or the quantity of Zevherbi is now exposed from the bone, then raise your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, continue using your hand with the iron itself, or use another one if it has cooled down: until the bones appear, which I told you about.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and apply it to the wound, and place it on the spot: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place on the wound a dressing soaked in butter, and leave it on the spot until the burned tissue falls off.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with the Tetrapharmakon ointment until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have said that the more a wound remains open, it discharges pus; therefore, it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized down to the bone: and hold the cautery until something thick from the bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then scrape off what is burned from the bone, and then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that with the cautery one must proceed until the very end, so that it impresses a mark on the bone like a mold, such that the bone falls off, which happens as if shaped like a kirate: or an instrument that women place in small lettered designs: and they believe that vapors from the head are expelled from this place, and the wound should be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be treated until it is healed and firm.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	However, these two types of cautery do not seem to be necessary except for some people out of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And to let it be, in my opinion is better for his safety.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head becomes weakened by the dissolution of its natural continuity, as we have testified with other limbs; especially when the patient's head is weak by nature. And indeed, the first type of cautery seems to be safer and better to me, and I use it: therefore, work with it for the sake of health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	Regarding the method of cauterizing the head when there is pain throughout the entire head.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When chronic pain occurs throughout the entire head and it persists in the patient, they use hot compresses, decoctions, purgatives for the head, oils, and emplastries.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been treated with one type of cautery that we have mentioned and none of those treatments help: then consider the situation.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the patient's head is of strong natural constitution and is not weak, but feels intense cold, then cauterize with a different type of cautery beneath it slightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over the entire circumference of the head with a cautery, but do not penetrate the skin, and expose a quantity of bone as we have described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with one type of cautery at the back of the head, in a place called the vasa, which is where the fontanelle is located: and raise your instrument in this area, but do not expose the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For this causes him great pain, and a pain different from that of the other anterior parts of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will call this Cautery in its place: and it is necessary that there be a cauterization for the horns of the head, and its occiput more subtly with a cauterization, which cauterizes the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	关于用烧灼疗法和铁进行偏头痛烧灼的方法。
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	当头部某部分发生疼痛和炎症，或者疼痛蔓延至眼睛，并且使用清洁药物治疗头部后仍未改善整体状况时：那么烧灼疗法在此处有两种方式：一种是使用锐利的燃烧药物进行烧灼；另一种是用铁进行烧灼。
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	使用锐利的燃烧药物进行烧灼的方法是，取一根芦苇，剥去其外皮，并从两侧削尖其末端。
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	然后，在出血期用宽扁的放血刀切开疼痛部位，直到皮下出现一个可以插入芦苇的地方。
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	因此，将其插入皮下，直到看不见为止：然后用适当包扎的绷带固定其上，并保持十五小时，之后解开它，取出芦苇，在接下来的两天或三天内不要更换绷带：之后在患处放置浸入牛脂中的蜡块，直到伤口产生脓液：最后使用药膏治疗，直至痊愈。
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with certain burning medicines, which I have written about in the twelfth treatise, on burning medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	But cauterization of it with iron is done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	A cautery tool, which has the following form.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a Nail because the shape of its head is like that of a nail, which has some curvature, and in the middle of it there is a small protrusion.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the location and keep your hand steady: and you should rotate the iron gradually with speed: and the amount that is burned should be according to the thickness of the skin, as its middle part.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand so that the artery below is not burned, and thus avoid an excessive flow of blood.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak a cloth in salt water and place it on the location, and leave it for three days: then apply a cloth with butter: afterwards treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this headache with the second cutting edge of the cautery tool.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And be careful not to cut an artery in this headache, not an old one particularly.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in an old headache.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When treating a headache, follow what we have said about previous treatments and the division of diseases, and if the treatment does not suffice: and you see from the illness that what we said about the first cauterization with medicine or with fire is insufficient, then it is necessary to heat the cautery tool until it whitens. After marking on the location of pain with a line whose length is half a finger's width, or nearly so, place your hand and cut until you reach the artery, and proceed until you reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, you must be careful not to burn the side or the nerve that moves the lower jaw, which is moved during chewing, so that spasm does not occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be careful about the preservation and protection of the blood flow from the artery that has been cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For there is fear in cutting it, especially for one who does not know what they are doing, and who is neither skilled nor experienced: and they abandon the procedure because of this.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will provide guidance on managing the blood flow from an artery cut according to its manner and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see that this cautery is not sufficient for the patient's condition and you notice that the patient's body can tolerate a cautery in the middle of the head, as we have described, treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the cautery that we mentioned in the chapter on the extraction of an artery using a cautery with two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cautery is better and more beneficial.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	Concerning the method of applying cautery for pain in the Ears.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the Ear due to cold and is treated with dissolving agents and other treatments as we described in the division, but the pain does not subside, then apply cautery with fire: and it is called a Punctum, whose form is as follows.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then apply the Punctum around the entire ear after igniting it, as it revolves: or around each ear if pain is present in both simultaneously.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And move away from the root of the ear with the cautery slightly, after marking the places with wax: and let the quantity of the cautery be ten points on each ear, or so.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then treat the places until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	§ On the Method of Cauterizing in Torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Torture which is treated with cautery is not caused by anything other than types that occur due to phlegm, as we said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And avoid cautery for the type that occurs due to dryness and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this type of torture with herbs, purgatives, and gargles, and your treatment is not effective, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient three times: once near the root of the ear, and the second slightly below its usual position, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the affected part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	Since softening does not occur except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of the cautery is such that you should cauterize with the cautery directly at the upper extremity of the ear near the horn of the head slightly: and another at the temple: its length should be according to the length of a thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cautery until the quantity of half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a type of knife, whose form has been described beforehand; however, it should not be much less subtle than that, as you see: and it must be somewhat thicker than a knife.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the areas that came before until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	§ On the method of cauterizing in ancient apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy becomes chronic and your treatment does not help, and the patient does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on each horn of his head, one in the middle of the head, as we said, and one at the back of the head, as was described before: and the method of cauterizing should be as previously described.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	It is also cauterized with a cautery over the mouth of the stomach: and this is more of a last resort.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat it as was described previously.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	§ On the method of cauterizing in cases of forgetfulness.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary to give the patient large doses of hysrae (a type of medicine) and pills that purify the brain first and foremost.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the patient's head entirely, and apply a plaster made from mustard, as described in the chapter on plasters, to the back of his head: do this several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is indeed the method of cauterizing: and perform it according to the same order that I described there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If it is cured by that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make for him three cauteries on the back part of his head, which should extend from the upper part of the head down to the lower part of the eye: and place between each caustic the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then apply the cautery as described previously.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If you wish to add more and the patient can tolerate it: then make a cautery in the middle for him.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish to add more: then cauterize him above the two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat him until he is healed: let the cautery be olive-shaped according to the form that was described.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in paralysis and for softening.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	You must proceed with the cleansing of the head using hares' fat, as we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the patient: afterwards cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of the head, and a cautery above each horn of the head, and a cautery above the back part of it, and three on the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If you need more softening in a severe illness and the patient can tolerate it: then cauterize him with four cauteries on the vertebrae of the back, and make the last one until much of the skin is burned away, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then treat it until it is healed: and thus apply the olive caustic.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic is not cauterized unless the epilepsy is due to phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, you should cleanse his brain first with hysop and with the remaining treatments that we mentioned in the division: when the patient is severe or can tolerate medication intake.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, it is a child who cannot tolerate medication, then a gargle and brain-cleansing chewing substances are administered before that for many days with the improvement of food quality.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, and cauterize it with one cautery in the middle of the head according to the method described; and with another cautery on the back of his head, and on every horn of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient is strong and can tolerate it, then cauterize him with the cauteries that I described for one who has paralysis and relaxation of the body over the vertebrae of the neck and back: and let the olive cautery be applied according to the method previously mentioned.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If, however, the patient is a child, then apply a fine cautery according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the method of cauterizing in melancholia.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted moisture and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with the cauteries that we described for one who has paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess tendency towards it, and the patient's body is moist, then give him something to drink that will cleanse his brain, as was mentioned in the division: then shave the patient’s head, and afterwards make a properly made bandage of linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the patient, sitting squarely, should be held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more appropriate to use ancient sheep's butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it over a moderately heated fire, to a temperature that can be tolerated by the finger when it is inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then empty it onto the middle of the patient's head in a circle, and leave it until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the patient once every week, along with the rest of their good regimen, until they are healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small punctures with the cautery: keep your hand near it, and let there be a smell from it.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this type of cauterization moistens the brain with a certain quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place a cloth soaked in butter or chicken fat on it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	Regarding the method of cauterizing with water descending to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the signs of water in the eye become apparent to you, as I mentioned in the division, then begin and have the patient drink something that will cleanse his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep him away from all moistures, and make him sit in a bath for several days of fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then instruct him to shave his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize him above both temples with two cauteries, if the beginning of water descent occurs in both eyes at once: or from one side, if the beginning of water occurs in one eye: and cut off all veins and arteries that are under the skin with a cauterium: and let the cauteries be long in width across the temples: and beware of blood flow.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see something coming from it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them, and caution against blood flow.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized on the neck, under two bones, with two cauteries extended to the end.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in ancient tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient and persistent: and they are above veins and arteries that are on the outer surface of the head, it is verified that this is from excess cold, phlegmatic fluids: then cauterize with the same cauteries as I described for the beginning of water descending, a cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries above both temples, and two cauteries on the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need to add more, then cauterize him on the entire side of the eye carefully, above the end of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	Of the method of cauterizing for nasal polyps.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it as we have said in the division, and the medication does not suit: then hurry, and give to the sick person three nights in drink: then shave his head, and cauterize him with a medium cautery, using an olive-based cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize him with a cautery of the nail using two cauteries, above both eyebrows slightly under the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And be careful to avoid the artery, so as not to strike it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the cautery of the nail.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	Of the method of cauterizing for the softening of the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened due to illness or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, using this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize him above both eyebrows slightly with two cauteries on all parts: and they should be distant from both temples: and the length of the entire cautery should be according to the lengths of the eyebrows: and do not place your hand last with the cautery, but according to the amount that the third eyelid is burned.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of the lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	Of the method of cauterizing the eyelid when the hairs turn and irritate the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery is used in two ways: either with fire, or with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In the cautery with fire, however, instruct the patient beforehand to remove his hair, if he is one of those who shave it, until it has grown out and become even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	但如果它在他的起源处刺痛他：那么用布条绑住他的眼睛，使它们不要移动，直到伤口愈合。
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	当它们愈合并变得平整时，把病人的头部放在你的臂弯里：然后用烙铁在他的眼皮上标记，标记形状像我的叶子：标记的起点应该靠近毛发。  
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a pad soaked in egg white or in slippery elm mucilage over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply the cautery, which has this form.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize gradually in many applications over the figure you have marked, until the surface of the skin, which is shaped like a myrtle leaf and appears distinctly, is burned.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of your work being successful is: if you see the eyelid already contracting and the hair raising up around the puncture of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Raise then your hand: and let him be for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place a pad with butter on it until the eschar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat him with an ointment until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any of the hairs return after an hour and the eyelid becomes soft, then apply the cautery to that place again as you did initially.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If the hairs are on the lower lid, then cauterize it until the hairs rise to their natural place, and become even so that they do not irritate the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	Regarding the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is to instruct the patient to let the hairs grow out until they become even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from paper or cloth the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap and from lime that has not absorbed moisture an ounce each or about that amount; then pound them together finely, and make it quickly so that it does not cool.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from it and place it on a sheet of paper as the shape of a myrtle leaf, and put it above the eyelid of one eye or two.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a cloth soaked in egg white; and let the head of the sick person rest in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger on the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you should move it each time the patient feels a biting sensation from the medicine: for he will find its bite like that of fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore he continues to feel this biting sensation, then let go of the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the biting sensation subsides, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And observe if you see the eyelid rise as it does when contracting with heat or with incision; that is good: and if not, then apply more of the medicine to a place where it has not been applied previously, and does not darken, until your work evens out, and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place a cloth soaked in butter on it until the burnt skin is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with a diaphoretic ointment or another suitable one until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And you must be careful above all things during the operation that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid softens after several days and something from the lashes causes irritation in the eye, then apply the medicine again to that place which is softened by the eyelid, just as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the leaf of the myrtle.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that the eyes of people differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, let your consideration be based on this: the way of righteousness is not hidden from one who has a passion for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in a lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula, and the treatment does not succeed as we said in the divisions of diseases: then you must cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place his head in your lap, and have an assistant hold the patient's head between their hands in such a way that it does not move or jolt.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply Colchicum infused in egg white or mucilage of psyllium to his eye. Then use a cautery heated with fire, which has this form.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	It should be concave, like the shape of an eagle's feather from one end, where the cautery is made. And if you wish it to penetrate to the other end, and if you want it to be held up in this way, do so.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	This is indeed better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula if it is open, and remove the pus from it, and clean it: and if it is not open, then open it, and remove its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then apply a cauterizing agent to it, which should be heated very strongly.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand near the cauterizing agent for a moment between your eye and the side of the nose to ensure that your hand does not slip or disturb the patient: then place the cauterizing agent on the fatty tissue of the eye area and burn it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you reach the beginning of the cauterization near the opening, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not, then apply the cauterizing agent once, or twice if necessary: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then apply cotton with butter, and treat it with a healing ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If forty days pass and it does not heal, then apply a sharp corroding medicine until the opening is revealed: and scrape it as described in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing the fistula, which some earlier practitioners have described.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Examine the location of the fistula and locate it: then place a fine cannula, known as camahan subtile, in the fissure, which has this shape.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a quantity equal to one drachma of melted lead, and hold your hand with the tube securely, and do not move the patient at all so that the melted lead does not run or reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And you should place on the sick person's eye cotton infused in egg white, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the place of the fistula and heals it with a marvelous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed as we have said with cauterization and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer the nostril opening and redirect the fistula to follow the course of the nose, according to where it will come to its own proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in splits of the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Fissures often occur on the lip, which are called Pili, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you treat these fissures, as we have said in the division of diseases, and if treatment does not suffice, then prepare a small knife-shaped cautery with fire, in this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its concavity be according to the fineness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the heated cautery quickly on the fissures until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with pitch until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in a fistula of the mouth.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum, or on the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: then it forms pus and bursts; afterward it becomes old and the pus runs, forming a fistula; then when you treat it and regular treatment is not sufficient, you should heat a cautery according to its size, so that it fits into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the heated iron into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand until the heated iron reaches the depth and end of it: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it after that, according to what we have said about treatment until it is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If the pus is therefore removed and healing occurs, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place and remove the corrupted part as it comes to its end.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	Concerning the method of cauterizing the Gums and Softening the Teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum softens due to moisture and the teeth become loose, and treatment with medicines is not effective: then place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then take a cautery instrument, the form of which will be described later. Place the tube over the tooth and insert the heated cautery quickly into it. Hold your hand for a short while until the patient feels the heat of the fire reaching the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And raise your hand: then repeat the cautery several times as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient fill his mouth with salt water and hold it for one hour: then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the loose tooth becomes firm, the softened gum is tightened, and the corrupted moisture dries up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Of the method of cauterizing for tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the pain of a tooth is due to coldness, or there is coldness within the tooth, or it is caused by a worm, and treatment with medicines does not help: then cauterization should be applied in two ways: either with butter cauterization, or with fire cauterization.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cauterization with butter is done as follows: take cow's butter and heat it in an iron spoon or basin.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a cloth and wrap it around the handle of the heated spoon.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then dip the cloth in the boiled butter and place it quickly on the painful tooth, holding it until it cools. Repeat this several times until the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, dip a piece of wool or cloth in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth, then hold an ignited iron above it until the heat reaches the deepest part of the tooth cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization with fire is done by using a tube of brass or iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And there should be some thickness in the tube so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the diseased tooth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then heat the cauterization tool, which will be in the shape of a tube, and place it on the tooth. Hold your hand there until the cauterization tool cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be removed either on that same day or the following day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary in applying that cautery that the patient fill his mouth with good butter and hold it for one hour; then he spits it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Apply the cautery with whichever end you wish, as is possible: and this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	Regarding the method of applying cautery in strophulus.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIIII.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When strophuli are caused by phlegm and cold moist humors, and do not respond to digestion through medicines, and you wish to digest them quickly: then use a concave cautery, whose form is as follows.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open ends, so that smoke can emerge from the cautery at the other end: and place it lit upon the swelling once, and a second time if you need it, until it reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then place the cautery according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and place a cloth infused in butter on it, until what the fire burned off is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with tooth ointment until it heals to the shape of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	Regarding the method of applying cautery for hoarseness of voice and constriction of breath.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the moistures overcome the channel of the lungs, and especially when this is accompanied by cold temperament, then it is necessary that the patient be evacuated first with soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it at night near the root of the throat in a depressed area: and be careful not to proceed with the cautery to the throat, nor on the skin, unless necessary.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery near the joint of the neck at the end of the last vertebra: and let the cautery be needle-like according to the method that has been described.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the method that has been described until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	¶ On the method of cauterizing for diseases of the Lungs, and Cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When the cough and disease of the lungs are due to cold humidities, and the patient does not have fever nor consumption, and the illness is not chronic: then cauterize it with two cauteries above the clavicle in depressed, soft, empty areas.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two nipples: and let the cautery be tube-shaped according to the form that was described previously.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.
