And if you wish for your cautery to be done by puncturing with a cautery called Punctum, whose form was described previously in the piercing of ear pain: and let there be points from thirty points up to nearly another set.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the method that has been described until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let it have a cautery with three branches: in this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore, use it for cauterization when you do with it one application to make three cauterizations.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	Regarding the method of cauterization in Titillico, in shoulder dislocation.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the helper is dislocated due to humidity and does not return to its proper position at the time of its return from the dislocation until it becomes accustomed to the act of returning, then it is dislocated by a slight movement as we have already testified about it. Then you must first reduce the dislocation.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the patient should be laid supine on their back, or on their healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then raise the skin that is on the inner side of the elbow with your left hand fingers: and if the joint is dislocated towards the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then have a cautery with two branches heated by fire.
Cuius forma est haec.	Its form is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of the cauterization will be with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes the cauterization is done with a cautery having three branches, thus the figure of the cauterization then has six points: and the branches are according to the fineness of the stretched skin.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of the cautery having three branches.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one is added to this method, which is why there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place crushed leeks with salt on the cauterized area.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then ensure the patient remains calm so that the affected limb is not moved for some time until it becomes stronger.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is upward, and this rarely happens, then cauterize it above the shoulder with a nail cauterization or by puncturing with multiple cauteries.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is strengthened, and the moisture is removed: and the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	Regarding the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and excessive moisture occur in the stomach, and they continue to affect its condition, causing an increase in phlegm and persistent methods of treatment that are ineffective: then the patient must lie on their back, stretch out their legs, and extend their arms.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries: one of them should be as large as the width of one digit under the chest cavity, another using a nail cauterization, and two more below on both sides of the first cauterization, until the shape formed by the cauteries is triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And space them apart so that they do not connect when they form pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cauterization should be two-thirds the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And the shape of the cauteries should be according to this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cauterization in the middle of the stomach, it should be done in this form: and the cauterization made for this should be one according to a circular shape as follows.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by pricking for him who is afraid of this cautery: and it is, as you mark on the stomach a spot according to the size that you wish with wax: then cauterize it with the pointed cautery: then cure it with the treatment which preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	¶ On the manner of cauterizing for cold conditions.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When pain occurs in the epigastrium due to coldness and humidity, or from thick wind, until the superfluous elements exit naturally from its usual course and the patient is cured as we have said and it does not improve: then the patient should lie on his back with his neck raised, and mark three cauterization spots with wax below the hypochondria where a man's elbow reaches: and there should be a space between each spot equal to the thickness of a finger: and let each cautery be straight along the length of the body: and do not press your hand much with the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the amount to be cauterized be of a thickness equal to half the thickness of the skin without addition: and let the patient stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	但如果患者不能站立，那么让他躺下，伸直双腿，并举起双臂。
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is possible for you to cauterize these spots with a needle cautery when you have subtlety and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And be careful not to proceed too far with the cauterization so that the thickness of the entire skin is burned, leading to the burning of the whole body and reaching the intestines: for the skin there is thin, therefore be aware of this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	Concerning the method of cauterizing abscesses of the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When an exit appears, and you wish to know whether the abscess is in the flesh of the liver or in its covering: then if it is in the flesh of the liver, the patient experiences a constant pain without acute suffering; but if it is in the covering of the liver, there is both severe pain and sharp acuteness. And you will see that it has exhausted the efforts of his physicians to treat it.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, the patient should lie supine with his neck raised.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then shape the area of the abscess with a hot iron; then apply the cautery, which resembles a rod, while it is heated.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with it once, until the entire skin is burned and reaches the soft tissue, until all the pus has been expelled; then treat it as you would an abscess that has burst, until it heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And one should not use this type of cautery unless their study and practice in the art of medicine are extensive, and through their hands have frequently encountered such ailments with experience; then they may venture to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	However, for me, it is better to leave it as it is.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that a cautery should be applied to cold pleurisy with the roots of birthwort in this manner.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And take from the roots of dry great Aristolochia one longer root which is found there, and let it be as thick as a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil: and set it alight on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cautery on what is between the fork and the neck, and with two small cauteries slightly inclined under the chin, on the part which is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauteries also on what is between the fifth and sixth rib slightly inclined towards the back: and with another cautery in the middle of the chest, and one above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And with three cauteries from the back: one on what is between two scapulas: and with two cauteries from the sides of the chest, below the one that is between the two scapulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And you should not press the cautery with your hand, but let it be applied to the skin so that it can be smelled.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancient ones have already said that there are people who use a cautery made of iron like a rod: they ignite it and insert it inside until it reaches the area between the ribs, where it is used near an abscess until pus comes out: as we mentioned in the case of an abscess on the Epatis.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with the cautery there is fear that either the patient will die immediately, or it will result in a place where a fistula forms, which cannot be healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	§ On the Method of Cauterizing the Spleen Head XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you treat the illness of the spleen, as we have said in the treatment among the division of illnesses, and your treatment does not help, then cautery is applied to it in three ways, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of these methods is to make three cauterizations, or four by marking along the length of the spleen according to the shape of the cauteries of Epates, whose figure precedes.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And there should be between each cauterization a space equal to the thickness of a finger, or slightly more.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And the method of the cautery, which we mentioned for the cautery of Epates, should be done evenly.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand with the cautery: and let the patient lie supine on their back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another method of cautery is as follows: take a cautery with two prongs, which we mentioned in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder: and lift the skin that is directly above the spleen, where the left elbow of the patient reaches: and when you lift the skin, do so according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert the two burning prongs until you penetrate the skin from the other side: then remove the cautery: thus four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize using a cautery with three prongs.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then treat the area after you let it emit pus for many days: for this is more effective than other methods mentioned earlier in the treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the method of cauterizing in Dropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	Cautery is not used in dropsy except when properly indicated.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat patients with dropsy using the methods of treatment that we have described in the division, and if the treatment does not improve their condition, then it is necessary to cauterize them with four cauteries around the navel, one on top of the stomach, another above the pubis, one over the spleen, two behind between the spine, one directly on the chest, and one directly on the stomach. The depth of the cauterization should be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then leave the cauterized area open so that it can release pus over time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not abandon the patient from treatment after cauterization; it is necessary to maintain two intentions for them: and with God's help, their healing will hasten.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The shape of the cautery used to cauterize the abdomen should be like a nail, as previously described. The shape of the cautery used to cauterize the back should be like an olive, as previously described.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the method of cauterizing the Feet and Legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When they become inflamed and filled with yellowish water in dropsy, you should cauterize on the back of the foot at a point between the third and fourth toes. Raise your hand with the cautery and do not twist it. Then raise your hand again: and do not repeat this process at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For lemon juice will flow, and let it be used as a cautery in this manner.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two cauteries on each leg, and let the cautery be made with the sharp edge of a knife: and let it be made along the length of the leg, one below the knee, and another below that, around the middle of the thigh: and above every hip joint, two cauteries: and leave the cautery open without treatment for a long time: so that some water may ooze from it: then treat it with what we have said previously.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in the treatment of the abdomen.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When there is a resolution of the abdomen due to cold and moisture, until the retaining and digestive powers in the stomach and intestines are weakened: and it is treated according to methods of treatment, but it does not heal: and you see the patient enduring a cautery of great power, then cauterize him with a large cautery over his stomach, as previously described for stomach cauterization with a circular cautery, and four fine cauteries around the navel, and with a fine clavicle-shaped cautery: and a large cautery above the alcalis, or with two such cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive moistures and the patient enduring this, then cauterize him with a cautery above the pubis, and a cautery over the entire ileum: and perhaps you will add two small cauteries above the stomach near the large one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For the treatment is progressing, whose aid does not err.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	Regarding the method of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old hemorrhoids or one that is caused by thick, cold humors or corrupted moistures and cannot be cured with the methods we described: then cauterize three times above the lower vertebra of the spine near the gluteal region in a triangular pattern, and cauterize below the navel at about two finger breadths.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is chilled and that the food does not digest, and you see his face becoming inflamed: then cauterize him above the stomach with a large cautery, as previously mentioned; and cauterize above the liver, and another one above the spleen with a needle-like cautery; leave the cautery open for some time; then treat him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	Concerning the method of cauterizing the wound after the removal of hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you remove a hemorrhoid, then ignite the cautery which resembles a rod.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the ignited cautery into the removed hemorrhoid; and move your hand until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which the blood flows: do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many hemorrhoids, then cauterize each one with the cautery as we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with ointments as appropriate until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery above the anal region, it is more severe in treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	Concerning the method of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not submit to the cutting and procedure that we have described in its place, and is afraid of it, he may perhaps be cured with cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When therefore a fistula occurs and persists, pus runs from it, and corrupted humors accumulate.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	It is therefore appropriate to examine it with a fine probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then determine the depth of the fistula using a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then heat the cautery, which is shaped like a rod.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert the heated cautery into the fistula, and determine how far it goes inside.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And apply the cautery repeatedly to it until all the corrupted tissues are burned away, once, twice, or three times, according to the necessity of the case.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And be careful not to burn the nerve, if it is there, or any large veins. Or if the fistula goes towards the bladder or the intestine, then be cautious around all these areas.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not perform this procedure unless the fistula is in a fleshy part and you consider that it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the area until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If the area seals up and matter is expelled from it, and it remains this way for a long time, then you will know that it has healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if no material is removed from it, then you know that it is penetrating, or there is a corrupted opening deep within it, or something like those mentioned above will come to mind in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	Paragraph on the Method of Cauterizing the Kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys due to cold or from thick wind, and it diminishes because of that for the sick person, then you should cauterize above the almethena above the kidneys, using cautery over the entire kidney with a nail-shaped cautery, whose preceding details have been mentioned previously.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we should cauterize it a second time at the almeidatus.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Therefore, three lines will appear.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore, they will be more effective for healing.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	Paragraph on the Method of Cauterizing the Bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and softening occur in the bladder due to coldness and moisture, such that the patient cannot retain urine, then cauterize it at the lower part of the pubis above the bladder, where the hairs of the pubic region begin, using one cautery from the right side and another from the left: and the length of each lateral cautery should be according to the width of the joint of the thumb: and cauterize it with an inferior dorsal cautery, or with two cauteries if you need them: and let these be according to the previously mentioned nail-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	Paragraph on the Method of Cauterizing the Uterus.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLII.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and dampness occur in the womb and prevent impregnation, corrupting her menstrual flow and delaying its provocation, causing pain upon their arrival, then it is necessary to cauterize three times around the navel, as we mentioned regarding the cauterization of the bladder, and once on the sacrum below the back, or twice: and the cautery should be shaped like a key.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	Concerning the method of cauterizing the ankle in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLII.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous humidities flow to the ankle region and become the cause of its displacement from its proper place: and the sign of this is that one leg is longer than the other when compared: and the location of the dislocation is found to be empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore, you should cauterize the affected area above the ankle pit with a cautery similar to a circle: after marking with pitch around the perimeter of the pit, as it revolves: and let the pitch fall in the center of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And the cautery should have the form that was mentioned earlier in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If you do not have this cautery available to you, then cauterize it three times with a large olive leaf cautery: and the depth of the cautery should be according to the thickness of the skin throughout.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	Concerning the method of cauterizing for sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the pit of the stomach, and the cause is cold and moisture: and the patient is treated as we have said in the division, but if this treatment does not help and the condition persists: then you must relieve the patient of thick humors with fetid pills, or artificial pills, and similar remedies.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cauterization is in two ways: either with caustic medicines or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Cauterization with fire is done in many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of which is to cauterize above the pit of the stomach with three triangular cauteries, in this manner.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make them either good or bad in depth.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And the space between each cauterization should be the width of a finger. Let the cautery be olive-shaped.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	At times, the cautery is applied in the middle above the pit of the stomach.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Therefore, there are four cauterizations.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose form was described earlier in the cauterization of dislocated stomachs: let it be a circle encompassing the entire navel area.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the skin entirely.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cauterization for sciatica when the pain is attached to the navel area itself and does not extend up to the hip and thigh.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends to the hip and thigh, then cauterize it with two cauteries above the hip, at the place where the patient points out the location of pain, and let your cautery on the splint be about four digits towards the wooded part: and let the cautery be knife-shaped.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cauterization should be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient indicates that the pain extends to near the toes, then cauterize it there where he points, with a puncture cautery, three, four, or more times if necessary.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he indicates that the pain is below the knee towards the thigh, then cauterize it there with one knife-shaped cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And be careful in all your cauterizations that you do not proceed with the cautery to such an extent as to burn a nerve or a major artery, and thereby cause harm or contraction for the patient.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I have indeed seen one and another of those who cauterized above the splint and proceeded too far in the cauterization, resulting in inflammation of the leg until a tumor extended to the foot, which became perforated and completely corrupted: then peritonitis occurred, followed by death.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If the pain is in both parts simultaneously, cauterize each one according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And certain wise ones have said that in the cauterization of an abscess, this is the method for the cautery.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a cautery like one made of iron, whose diameter is half the width of a palm: and let it be at its opening as thick as the core of a finger, or slightly less: and inside that cautery should be a third cautery.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let the space between each pair of forceps be the width of one thumb joint: and let the forceps be open on both sides: and let their height be about one or two thumb joints: and fit them with a handle made of appropriately shaped iron attached to the forceps.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then heat it in the fire until it turns red and sparks: then place it on a tray while the patient lies on their healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Cauterize him with three round cauteries at once.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then leave him for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	After that, apply plasters with butter: and leave the wound open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat him with ointment until he is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, we have used this type of cautery only rarely because of the fear caused by its appearance: and also because few are willing to endure it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Nevertheless, it is one of the good cauteries for those who can endure it and find the right place for its use.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	However, when using cautery with burning medicines, you should make two forceps with a perforated ring, into which the pin of the hinge descends from brass or iron, as long as the wall: their height should be about two thumb joints, or nearly so.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let the space between each of them be the width of a finger, and let them be open both below and above: and let them fit together according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it on the box of pitch, with the patient lying on their healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand strongly on the box of pitch.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour warm water, heated briefly with fire, between the two circles; keep it for a certain period of time: and let the patient tolerate its biting and burning, as he will find it feels like fire, until the biting subsides.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then raise your hand with the instrument, and wipe away the warm water from the pitch entirely with sweet water; then leave it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And place butter on it until the blackness of burning is removed: and leave it for several days, and pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For this is the final step in the treatment.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the hip or leg, make a statue in it that contains water, as you did with the pitch equally. 
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of warm water: and I have already written it in the chapter on the preparation of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take one part of alkali and one part of unslaked lime: grind both, and put them in a new pot whose lower part has a small hole, according to the quantity that can be ingested by the finger: place another earthenware pot underneath the first pot: then pour over the alkali and lime some sweet water so that it covers both with your finger: after which press them well with your hand: and leave the pot until the sharp water descends into the lower earthenware pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then collect all that water and pour it over another piece of lime: and boil it until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For then it will be very strong and sharp, which is used in many medical operations and in cauterizing other limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it accomplishes the work of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And among the medicines used to cauterize the thighs are turpentine, cardamom paste, and lime with soap, such that both are thoroughly mixed.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galenus recounted in his writings the treatment of an ancient man for pain in the thigh and sciatic vein: and he highly praised its effectiveness.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said that it did not require any other treatment, and that he was healed in one attempt. He also mentioned that perhaps the patient entered a bath carried by others and emerged from it already cured.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it should be taken from green muslin: and if the green is not available, take the dry recent one. Grind it much with some fat and apply it to the thigh, where there is pain, or leg, or in the hip: and bind it, and leave it for three hours, or until the patient feels a soothing sensation of burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce him into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	Since his body becomes moist, introduce him into the tub.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain withdraws, and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that one must not use cauterization with these medicines unless after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides said that goat droppings, when used to cauterize the sciatic vein, are beneficial; and the cauterization is performed in this manner.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool, soak it in old oil, and place it on a deep spot between the big toe and the metatarsal bone, closer to the metatarsal bone.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat droppings and burn them in fire until they become charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place the charcoal on the wool and leave it until it extinguishes.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat it.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not cease doing this until the sensation reaches the joint and the pain subsides.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called Vaccinum cauterization.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	¶ On the Cauterization of Back Pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIIII.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Pain in the back sometimes occurs due to many causes, whether from an accident, a blow, excessive evacuation, or similar factors, resulting from the infusion of cold and moist matter. However, cauterization is applicable only in this single case, which results from the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Therefore, after the evacuation of the patient with stinking pills and similar treatments, three lines should be made across the part where the pain is on the back's width. Mark five cauteries or more in each line according to what comes from the patient's tolerance and strength: and let the cauterization be done with a cautery point.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries using a needle-shaped cautery, in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Regarding the method of cauterizing for the initial stage of Scoliosis.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLV.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This illness often occurs in very young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its onset in children is that it occurs with constriction during breathing when raising and moving: and you will find at the last vertebrae of the back and those around it that they have begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you see this and wish to treat it, then cauterize it with a cautery that is circular in this manner.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And place the cautery evenly over all parts of the vertebrae: and if you wish, cauterize around the vertebrae with a needle-shaped cautery in two lines or three: and let the points be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then treat the area until it heals, as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And be careful not to administer the cautery in a hump caused by nerve spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	Regarding the method of cauterization for gout and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of joints are caused by cold humidities that spread to any part of the body, then when such pains occur in the feet, it is the custom among physicians to call this condition gout properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	Therefore, when gout caused by cold is treated with methods of treatment and the pains do not subside, then cauterization removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is such that you should cauterize the area after evacuation around the joint of the feet with multiple cauteries: and let the cauterization be olive-based.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you need to puncture the top of the foot, then do so with a puncturing cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	If the pains ascend to the knees or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize it above each knee with three or four cauteries from all sides, using this same Caelius's cautery.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If you find it necessary to use this cautery more extensively, then proceed with the cauterization.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not immerse your hand with the cautery, but let it be about as thick as the thickness of the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If the pains ascend to the knees and the back, then administer what we have mentioned about cauterization in its respective chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pains are in the hands only, then puncture around the finger joints, as two lines would encircle them.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If pain remains in the fingers, then prick them, over every knot prick it, and over the web of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If pains rise after days to the elbows or to the shoulders, then cauterize both from all sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not remove the sick person from good treatment, from taking medicine.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if good treatment is done, and phlegm is removed, he will be healed with the help of God along with this cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, and the intestine or colon descends to the testicle, and it is just beginning: then you should instruct the patient to fast on that day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use mild laxatives so that the feces may leave his stomach.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then have him sit between your hands on his back: and instruct him to hold his breath until it comes out, or the colon or intestine becomes apparent.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and mark it with a cautery below the rupture above the pubic bone, with a sign whose end is similar to half a circle towards the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then apply the cautery with fire, which has this form, until it becomes white and sparks fly.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or colon to its concavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let the assistant place his hand on the area so that the intestine does not come out: and you have now opened between the legs of the patient, and placed a cushion under him, and another servant is above his legs, and another holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery on that mark, with your hand holding the cautery upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it until you reach the mouth with it: or try again with it another way, if you did not succeed reaching the mouth on the first attempt.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe from the exit of the intestine during your cautery time, so that you do not burn it, and thus cause great harm or even death to the patient.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not reach the mouth with the cautery, your procedure is ineffective.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary for the cautery of children to be fine, according to their size.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat with the remaining ointments until it is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the patient lie on his back for forty days until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary to provide nourishment for the duration of his treatment, which should ease his stomach: so that the intestine does not come out during strain and evacuation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wishes to rise after forty days, administer a properly made bandage and let him wear it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And he should be restricted from labor, overeating and drinking, and loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when this regimen is used, healing occurs completely.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will describe the treatment of ruptures with incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When ruptures occur in other parts of the abdomen and are beginning, and you wish that they not increase, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its size; and let what is burnt from then on be as thick as its third.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then treat it as I have said, and it will not increase.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some of the early ones have said that the rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, in this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After marking it with wax and placing a line that runs widthwise on the upper side of the rupture, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with a nail-shaped cautery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	Regarding the method of cauterizing for pain due to an accident or impact.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When pain occurs in certain limbs due to an accident or impact, and the pain persists for a long time without being relieved by medicines: then it is necessary to cauterize with a puncture cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And the cautery for every limb should be according to its size, and its condition, and its weakness, and its strength, and the location of the twist, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is healed by the first cauterization, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then apply the cauterization again.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Since it is customary for these pains to shift from one member to the adjacent one.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore, it is necessary to follow them with cauterization until the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Lepers are sometimes greatly helped by cauterization.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the type of leprosy that occurs due to the putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: when you wish to cauterize it, take care to consider it carefully.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If the leprosy is new and you have treated it as we mentioned in the division, and it neither descends nor remains stationary: and you fear for the patient that corruption will spread over his entire constitution: then cauterize him on top of five areas of the head: one in the middle of the head, a second below it towards the forehead near the end of the hairline, and two on each of the two temples, and one at the back above the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And leave your hand with the cautery for a short while, until it leaves a small impression and causes the outer layer to peel away: so that the expulsion of thick vapors from it may be alleviated, and cauterize the spleen as well, according to what has preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if the leprosy is already spread over the patient and appears clearly: then it is necessary to cauterize with these cauteries that we mentioned for the head, and one cautery at the tip of the nose, and two cauteries on each jaw, and two cauteries on the vertebrae of the neck, and six on the vertebrae of the back, and one large cautery near the coccyx at the base of the tailbone and one above it, in the middle of the sacrum: and two on each hip bone: that is, one on each hip bone, and two on each knee, and two on each shoulder, and two on each elbow, and cauterize him over every joint, from the joints of his fingers and toes: and cauterize over every heel of his feet, and the palms of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And be careful of the nerves that are above the heel, so as not to burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes it is cauterized with one cautery over the pubic bone, and another over the navel, and another over the epigastrium.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add cautery, it is more beneficial and more effective.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the sick person does not feel pain from cautery as healthy people do: because his body is already numbed.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary for the cauteries to be in size and shape according to the limbs and joints: as has been determined from the types of tools.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the cautery with flour of herbs mixed with honey, and continue the treatment until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in a state of numbness.
Caput L.	Chapter 50.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a limb is numb and is treated with medicines, oils, and plasters, and does not heal, then cauterize the numb limb with cauteries according to the size of the member or its shape.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery penetrate slightly into the thickness of the skin for a little while.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with an ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And sometimes cauterization is performed to treat numbness that affects the hand or foot at the vertebrae of the back near the exit of the nerves that move that limb: and the numbness is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But let no one venture upon that who is not wise in the anatomy of the members and the emergence of the nerves moving the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in Albaras.
Caput LI.	Chapter LI.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras is old and does not benefit from any medical ingenuity: then cauterize upon it with a deep cautery for a short while, according to the thickness of the skin, until the white part is removed and its color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with flour of the herb, lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnoglossa, and pigeon blood, and swallow blood: let there be an equal part of each. Mix all these together and apply them to a cloth, which should adhere to the affected area until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in Cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop its progression: then cauterize it with a circular cautery around it, as it spreads.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	The wise, however, have said that it should be cauterized with the ultimate cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	I do not agree with that, for I fear it will cause ulceration: and I have seen this happen several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	It is better to cauterize around it with a circle, as we have said: or with multiple cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an abscess that is delayed in maturing, either due to excess moisture causing it or because of the patient's age, such as being old and having little blood, or due to the timing, and you wish to hasten the maturation of the abscess, then cauterize around it with small cauteries by making many punctures.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then let it go.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hasten in maturing.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	但如果你想用烧灼器来穿孔它，那么点燃烧灼器，其形状如下。  
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of Adubelati until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be at a distance from where the patient lies, so that the flow may be eased by the pure [substance].
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in corrosive disease.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIIII.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A corrosive is nothing but a corruption in a limb that moves and corrodes it: just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If you see a corrosive in a place that can tolerate cautery with fire, then use many heated irons, both small and large, as appropriate for the location where the corrosive is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until the entire root of the corruption is destroyed, and nothing of it remains inside.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then leave it for three days, and apply ground sulfur with oil to the cauterized areas until all the scabs are removed, and all corruption is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then treat it with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If you see that after three days healthy flesh begins to grow, in which there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then apply the cautery to what remains of the corrupted areas.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And a corrosive is sometimes treated with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it indeed rises in the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	However, cautery with fire is more rapid in healing: and I have already mentioned its use with acute medicine in the division; therefore, accept it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	§ On the Method of Cauterizing in Keloids and Warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter LIV.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	This illness often occurs in the lower parts of the feet: and it is a coarse, filtered substance that injures the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And cautery in these cases is according to two methods: cautery with fire, and cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	When it comes to cautery with fire, make the cautery concave like an eagle's talon: let it be made of iron according to the size that can contain the wart from all sides: and let it have fine edges.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place the heated cautery on the wart.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then rotate the hand with the cautery around the wart until the cautery reaches the depth of the wart: and leave it for three days until it begins to release pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply a plaster to it with wild herbs crushed with salt: and leave the plaster on it overnight.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be eradicated from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then treat the area with a flesh-generating ointment until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they do not respond and often occur on the surface of the body, particularly on the hands and feet: then administer cautery with hot water to them: and take a tube made of copper, or iron, or an eagle's talon: and place it on the wart or growth.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small amount into the tube from warm water: hold your hand and rotate it slightly with pressure from your hand, so that the edge of the tube impresses itself on the root of the nail, and the warm water finds its way to the depth, to the root of the nail: and let the patient wait briefly over the warm water bath for one hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then release it, for the nail is extracted with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do this one after another until you have dealt with all of them that are in the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them after they are extracted, using what generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in Tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LVII.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When tremor occurs in someone due to cold in the nerve, or from quartan fever, or other causes: then it is necessary to cauterize it four or five times, above the vertebrae of the back, and between each vertebra with a cautery, and on the chest with a cautery, and above the stomach with a cautery.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For tremor ceases with olive cautery, and the recovery from cold illness is hastened.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	Regarding the method of cauterizing according to Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVIII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes ugly eruptions, that is, pimples, which are caused by corrupted thick matter, are expelled from the body.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore, when they appear, it is necessary to cauterize all boils on the head with a fine cautery using a branch of myrtle, whose tip has been set alight with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long aristolochia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lentil-shaped cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes they are cauterized at the beginning of their expulsion in this manner: and they do not increase; and the excess that causes them is ruptured, and they heal from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it must be done after evacuation with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	Regarding the method of cauterizing when blood flows from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Often it happens that blood flows from an artery that is cut near a wound, which occurs externally, or near the incision of an abscess, or cauterization of a limb, and similar cases: and it becomes difficult to stop it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When this happens to someone, then hurry with your hand to the opening of the artery, and place your index finger over it: and press it tightly until blood is trapped under your finger and nothing comes out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put small olive leaf cauteries and several larger ones into the fire: and blow on them until they become burning hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one of them, either small or large, depending on the wound and the location where the artery is disrupted, and place the cautery on it immediately after you quickly remove your finger: and hold the cautery until the blood stops.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If you drive it out by raising your finger from the opening of the artery, and extinguish the cautery, then take another cautery quickly, one which is prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Do not therefore stop doing it with one after another until the blood is severed.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful not to burn the nerve that is there, so that no other harm befalls the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to sever it, especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
