Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, the ends of it contract, and the blood is severed.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or let it be tied with a strong thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or apply medicines with the property of severing blood and bind it with a suitable bandage.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	He who administers the severing of it with a ligature, and binding with a cloth, or the placement of burning substances and similar treatments, does not truly help, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if it happens to someone and there is no doctor present, nor any medicine: then begin by placing the index finger on the opening of the vein itself, as we have described, and bind it very tightly until the blood is blocked above the wound, and over the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger shall not be removed; pour over it with very cold water continuously until the blood congeals, and swells, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile he should consider what it needs from cautery or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	¶ End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	¶ On Incision, Piercing, and Phlebotomy in Wounds and Similar Cases.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	In the First Chapter we have already discussed any illness in which it is appropriate to use cauterization and burning medicine, its occasions, causes, instruments, and forms of cauterizations.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed there chapters from the head down to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path: so that what is sought may be made clear to the seeker.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, it is necessary for you to learn, O sons, what is in this chapter from the fear mentioned in the first chapter about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And because of that, it is necessary to have a more cautious approach, since in the operations described in this chapter, there is often an excessive outflow of blood, with which life stands at risk during the opening of a vein, or incision above an abscess, or opening an exit, or treating a wound, or removing an arrow, or cutting near a stone, and similar procedures: from all of these fear and trembling arise, and death often ensues.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, do not let hesitation fall upon you, for at times methods of men with methods of illnesses fall upon you in this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For among them is one who becomes angry because of his illness, and death is light to him due to the vehemence he finds from his illness and the length of its malevolence.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when the illness is from fear, which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them is one who gives his trumpet call and enriches you with it, hoping for health, and his illness is perilous.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, you should not agree with him who comes to you from among them, whose method is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be stronger than your desire and your greed.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume on anything from that unless after certain knowledge, which verifies for you that to which a commendable succession leads.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use prognosis and indication in the treatment of all your patients regarding that to which healing would appropriately lead.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in that is your assistance for the acquisition of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, children, with His understanding, and may He not take from you direction and inspiration, for it is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And indeed, I have organized this Chapter by dividing it into sections, as it proceeded in the chapter on Cautery, from the neck to the feet: so that you may be relieved in seeking what you wish from it and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Concerning the treatment of water that accumulates in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this illness often occurs in children at birth: or when the midwife presses the child's head too harshly.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And it also happens at times for hidden reasons that are not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I myself have not seen this illness in anyone other than in children: and death hastened towards all of them. Therefore, it seemed to me to abandon the treatment of it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I myself saw a child whose head was filled with water, and his head enlarged every day until he could not sit on his own, due to the size of his head: and as the moisture increased, he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture accumulates either between the skin and the bone: or beneath the bone above the skull.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And if the treatment is needed when the moisture is between the skin and the bone, and the swelling is small, then you should make a single incision in the middle of the head with a width: and the length of the incision should be about two fingers wide, so that the fluid can run out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of the scalpel.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If the moisture is more increased and the swelling is larger, then make two incisions according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and its sign is that you see the seams of the head open from all sides: and water is depressed when you press it with your hand toward the interior, and this is not hidden from you: then you should make three incisions in the middle of the head, according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, remove all humidity.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then close the wounds with bandages and dressings.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then bind it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the bandage and treat the wound with lint and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not allow the head to be bound with uneven pressure.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the patient with all dry food having little moisture until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And there is another method for the incision, which involves considering where the size of the abscess and the collection of fluid are apparent.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Because sometimes there is more in the occiput, or at the top of the head, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore, proceed with the incision where you see the abscess and the collection of fluid; and cut it as much as possible.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And be careful not to cut an artery, and let there not be a flow of blood that causes the patient to die from that flow when evacuating the moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	¶ On Incising Arteries That Are Behind the Ears.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When someone suffers from catarrh affecting the eyes or chest, and it persists without improvement through medical treatment, then as a last resort, incising these two arteries is more advisable.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you wish to cut them, the patient should shave his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the area with a rough cloth so that the arteries become visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the patient should compress his neck with any cloth he has.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then observe where the vein pulsates.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations of both are in the depressed areas behind the ears; they are rarely hidden, except in some individuals.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with wax on both sides and cut each one with a sharp knife on either side, the incision reaching to the bone: and let this be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert the knife under the artery and cut it upwards with an upward incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And the length of the incision should be about two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood flows out in a pulsating manner, which leaps to the interior with frequent jumps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	但如果动脉不明显，那么你需要从耳朵量起，测量三个手指宽度的距离。
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with pitch, and cut until the mouth.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what must be let out of the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you will let more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	Do all of this according to the amount that appears to you from the strength of the patient and the fullness of their artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then examine the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if there is something left to do near the mouth of the wound, cut it so that a hot abscess does not occur; then dress the wound with lint made from linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	¶ On the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a person suffers from chronic headaches or acute catarrh due to acrid humors and heat in the temples, or severe chronic conditions similar to these: and they are treated with methods of medical care but it does not benefit them: then we have found that in such ailments, the extraction of arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have described.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them is to shave the hair that is on the temples and then locate the visible artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	Indeed, it is shown to you by its pulse, and it is rarely hidden except in a few people or extreme cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, then the patient should bandage their head with any cloth they have; then rub the area with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Put a vapor bath with warm water until it becomes clearly apparent to you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatula that I formed a little while ago.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then carefully scrape off the skin with it until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw the hook into it and pull it up, until you have pulled it out of the skin and made it emerge from the layers beneath it on all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is fine: then wrap it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from it a portion according to the amount by which its ends are stretched out and drawn together, so that there is no loss of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut and separated, the blood does not rise thoroughly.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then draw out six ounces of blood, up to three times.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then it is necessary to ligature it in two places with double strong silk thread or with alhohod cords so that it does not decay before the wound heals, and there is no loss of blood.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the excess tissue between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the opening, using a knife-cautery: until its ends are cut and it will hold in place for the same work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better to work, unless the patient has a fever, or if the constitution is heated.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Since cautery is one of those things that helps to finish off humidities.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore, it is a better remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the arteries have been extracted, it is necessary for the place to be filled with old cooked material: and poultices properly prepared should be placed over it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the treatment, it should be cured with drying medicines that promote flesh growth and with pitch until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If during the operation a flow of blood occurs from an artery, then hurry to cut it with cautery, or fill the place with cotton wool; and press your hand until the blood is stopped.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If none of those things are present for you, then place your finger on the place until the blood clots.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And apply the place with water of extreme cold until the sharpness subsides and it is constricted as necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because it is lighter and easier to extract the artery, you should cauterize the vein with this cautery having two knives: let the sharpness of both knives be similar to that of an awl.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they have much less sharpness than the two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Because if they are as sharp as two knives, both require cooling: and they do not cut the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore, since there is a certain thickness to them, the heat of fire adheres to them, and the flesh is cut off quickly. Thus, this work is better than any other work, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between two knives be the thickness of a finger, after you mark two places with sealing wax: and place both very hot until they reach the mouth, and cut into the vein at two places: so that it stretches what is between its extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they do not become completely consolidated with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Regarding the treatment of constant sharp tear duct passages from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are constant and their passage is from veins that are above the exterior of the skull: and medicine does not help much with treatments for them, and you see the patient's face already reddened, and they feel a creeping sensation in their forehead, as if ants were crawling there: and their eyes are emaciated, moist, to the point that their hairs have been corroded by corrosion: and their eyelids are heated from the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients used this operation for their treatment, and they called it treatment with a sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And you should instruct the patient to shave the hair that is on their forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions on the forehead equidistant along its length: and let the length of each cut be about two fingers wide, with one in the middle of the forehead according to the length of the nose, the second slightly off-center from the movement of the jaw muscles, and the third on the other side: and be careful not to cut into the arteries that are on both sides: and extend your hand away from the connection of the two mandibles, and let the total length of all incisions be the width of three joined fingers: and have a piece of sponge prepared or several dried cloths with which you can dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert a probe with two sharp ends, the form of which is as follows.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision on the side of the temple to the second incision: and remove with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, as if doing so over the mouth.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then remove this probe and insert into the first incision again another instrument called a sharp spatula, which is blunt on one side and not sharp on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side towards the flesh attached with the skin, and its blunt side towards the bone: and push it until it reaches the median fissure: and remove with it all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision continues until it reaches what appears under the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do this in the median fissure until you reach another fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an amount of blood flows out, press the areas from clotted blood fragments.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place a piece of old pottery over every fissure, and put poultices soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar on them.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And ensure that a warm abscess does not occur.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day, remove the bandage, and administer much infused liquid with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then apply the ointment called basilicon and other remedies used for wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On the treatment of acute tears and catarrhs originating from the interior of the head and affecting the eyes.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute, sharp, and persistent catarrhs occur to someone, and you see their eyes becoming narrowed, small, and already appearing weakened: with the eyelids ulcerated, hair falling from them, and a sharp pain deep in the head accompanied by sneezing: then consider these symptoms, for such substances and catarrhs do not arise except from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the better treatment for them is as follows.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it involves instructing the patient to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make an incision in the forehead, either one down the middle or slightly across it, and start with the incision from the left temporal area to the right temporal area: and let the incision go up to the bone: keep your hand away from the temples, which move during chewing, until the bone is exposed: and dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two edges of the incision with an old pot shard or linen threads.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then stitch it closed from above with bandages: and soak the bandages in wine and oil so that a hot abscess does not occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you remove it and see that the hot abscess is beginning to subside: then it is necessary to rub the bone until new flesh begins to grow on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with a drying regimen that causes flesh to grow: just as if you take two parts from wheat flour and four parts from colophony: and prepare from them a plaster, and apply it at the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	Concerning the Treatment of What Falls Upon the Ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Anything that falls into the ear is one of four types: either a mineral stone, or something like a stone, such as iron and glass; or it comes from a plant, such as peas and beans; or it is a fluid substance, such as water, vinegar, and things similar to them; or it is some kind of animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone falls into the ear, or something like a stone among those things that do not add to it and do not grow in the ear, expose the Ear alone: if you see the stone, then distill something from violet oil or sesame oil into the Ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the removal of it, and make the person sneeze with something induced, and plug the nose at the onset of a sneeze, after which you place around the ear pieces of cloth or wool, and stretch the ear upward.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Indeed, it often exits with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If however it does not exit, then administer its removal with forceps, that is, fine pincettes: the form of which is as follows.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If it therefore exits with the forceps, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer its removal with a fine blunt hook of few folds.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If it does not come out through that [method], then make a tube of copper, and insert the end of the tube into the hole of the ear much, and remove what is around the tube with a soft cloth softened with oil, so that there is no way for wind except through the tube: then draw it out with your breath strongly.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For it often comes out as we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If it does not come out this way: then take a small amount of birdlime or viscum, that is, prepared gluten with which birds are caught, and place it on the end of the probe after you have wrapped something suitable around it: then insert it into the hole of the ear easily after you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If it does not come out with all the methods we have described, then hurry to cut it open before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of cutting should be such that the phlebotomist first draws blood from the head: and let him draw blood from the patient according to the measure of his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then have the patient sit between your hands, and turn his ear upward, and make a small incision at the root of the ear near its fatty part in a depressed area: and let the cut be in a crescent shape until you reach the cartilage: then remove what is possible for you with your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then treat the incision quickly and with care from your hour onward until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If something falling into the ear is one of those grains that grow and swell: then administer its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not yield to you for removal, then take a thin, fine spatula in this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And use it to remove that type of grain from the ear, and do not attempt this when you think the grain has become moistened by the vapor of the ear until you have broken it into many pieces: then extract them with hooks or with a fine forceps, or by suction, as we have said, for its extraction is thereby made easier.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	In the case of water that enters the ear, the patient must use sneezing with a prepared solution first: and then he should fill his ear with some boiled salt water. And he should lie on the side where the water is in the ear.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If it comes out through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if it does not: then take many stones, as long as a finger, thin and soft, and warm them with fire for a little while, and let the patient insert one of them into the ear canal: and jump on one foot from that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Do not stop doing this with stone and stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water will come out such that you should take one from parchment or reed, and insert one end into the ear: and light the other end with fire until it burns extensively.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then insert another reed and do this many times until all the water comes out: and remove it with a tube as was mentioned regarding the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In extracting an animal entering it, if it is of small body, like a flea and the like, treat it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of large body, which appears to the senses: then administer its extraction with forceps and hooks: and this matter is easier than all those held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In extracting a worm generated in the ear, when you treat it as we said in the division and in the chapter on distillation, and your treatment does not benefit: then you must look at the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something appears there from worms, then extract it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If however nothing appears there, then take a tube, which has this form, narrow below, wide above: and insert the fine end into the ear according to the amount that the patient can tolerate: then suck with it forcefully.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this multiple times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If however they do not obey you and come out, then scrape around the tube with a curette, as I said about stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not come out as I said: then administer distillations which the ancients have already used for killing worms: and you will find this in the chapter on distillation.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your application be with this instrument, through which you pour oil and medicines into the ear, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it of silver or brass, narrow at the bottom, with a small hole, and wide at the top.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it therefore be such that the part pushing what is in the concavity of the tube be made properly of air.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a rod and wrap its tip with soft cloth properly; then pour oil, juice, or whatever of these medicines into the tube, and place it in the ear. Then insert the rod with the cloth above it, and press it gently with your hand until the oil is pushed into the concavity of the hearing organ, and the patient feels it internally. And what is poured into the ear should be warmed slightly over fire; beware that nothing very cold distills into it, for medicine does not tolerate such conditions.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	¶ On the Treatment of Ear Wax Blockage.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes infants emerge from their mothers' wombs with their ears not perforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens to some people that ear wax blockage occurs in the ear canal due to a wound or flesh grown there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this blockage sometimes occurs deep within the ear canal, where it cannot be seen; and at other times it affects the outer part of the ear canal slightly, and can be seen.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which occurs deep within the ear and cannot be seen is difficult to treat in most cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And when the blockage can be seen, you should place the affected ear in sunlight and look into it. If you see a visible blockage, open it with a fine probe whose shape is as follows: its tip should have a small width and one part should be sharp, while the rest of the probe should be smooth on both sides so that it does not harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If there is an overgrowth of flesh in the passage of the ear, hold it with a fine hook and cut it with great ease until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the overgrowth is deep within the ear, then take a fine and flexible probe and heat it slightly with fire; then insert it into the passage of the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you detect an overgrowth along with what the patient experiences as a heaviness of hearing, attempt to open it with ease; and be careful not to injure the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then apply liquid cerate according to the size of the hole, which you have wrapped in Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are sure of the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take cerate and mix it with rose water, and sprinkle finely ground sugar over it, then use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see that the ear is already becoming abscessed, then it is necessary to extract the cerate and allow it with new cerate, which you wrap in a preparation made with rose oil, until the abscess softens; then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If bleeding occurs, then soak a sponge or cloth in cold water and apply it to the ear; and use the remaining treatment that stops the flow of blood, as described in the chapter on cautery.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Concerning the treatment of eyelid tumors (Altheli).
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These eyelid tumors that occur on the eyelids are sometimes moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, you should hold them with forceps: or with a hook, and cut them from their roots with scissors.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place ground wheat on the wound sites.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lentil-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterizing them is better after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often return when something remains of their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned up, and they do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Concerning the treatment of styes in the eyelids.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	It often happens in the eyelids that something occurs which resembles a sty in its strength and hardness, and because of this it is called a grandine. It is an aggregation of thick moisture in the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The procedure for treating them is to first determine if it is a grandine that appears on the eyelid and moves to all parts, and if its resolution is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore, find a fissure in it along its width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it from all sides with ease until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then hook it with a hook and remove it.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If, however, it does not prepare itself for removal unless you penetrate the eyelid with a small incision, then it causes some harm to the patient.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the crack is large, then join it with a suture and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For an ointment restores it and makes it heal.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if a foreign object has shifted towards the inner ear towards the inner surface, then turn the eyelid inside out, and retrieve the object with a hook; besides which, you may need to make an incision and press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the eyelid is stretched due to an incision, it does no harm.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the removal of the foreign object with salt water, and treat the area with something that promotes healing until the patient is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	Concerning the treatment of chalazion of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fatty substance that forms in the eyelids, and it most often occurs in children. It burdens their eyes, causing them to have catarrhs in the mornings, so much so that they cannot look at the light of the sun because tears rush to their eyes. As a result, you see them lying with their faces down always, and sleeping with it on their eyelids, which are moist under the eyebrows due to inflammation. The swelling of Axirnath is visible, and when you press the area with your fingers, you can feel the Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of treatment is for the patient to place their head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a piece of linen and prepare on it myrtle gum, and make from the myrtle gum a circle according to the size that Axirnath contains on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it on her and press with your fingers on all sides so that the Axirnath aggregates in the center of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that moisture with a probe incising fissures across the width, and let there not be a fissure larger than that which occurs in phlebotomy at a depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you must cut the skin entirely until you reach the Axirnath, for in many conditions the Axirnath proceeds from a fissure in the shape of a piece of white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	So remove it with the cloth that you have soaked between your fingers to the exterior: and you turn your hand to the right and left until it disperses: and be careful not to add anything in the fissure so as not to reach with a probe to the eye, and injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if the Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the fissure, you should gently add a little to the fissure until the Axirnath comes out.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then remove it as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then soak the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the area, and secure them with poultices.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are people who rub salt and place it in the concavity of the fissure, so that it liquifies what remains of that moisture.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If however an abscess hot to the touch should occur in a certain area, then treat it with calming plasters until it is healed.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Regarding the methods of Ataxmir for the eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft around the eye, resulting in it being irritated as it should not be.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs grow on the eyelids outside of their natural course and become entangled: then they harm the eye and cause various ailments to occur, such as continuous tears, softening of the eyelids, and opacity, until it becomes a cause for the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Ataxmir treats the eye according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as mentioned before in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or Ataxmir is treated by incision and suturing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with the use of tubes, as I will explain.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary to place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it turns correctly, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if it does not turn, insert a needle where the thread is located at the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread upwards, and let it be close to the actual hairs, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hairs grow: and pull the thread upwards along with the eyelid, and turn it with a probe.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelid with hairs added from the greater tear duct down to the lesser tear duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then remove the thread, and place a small piece of cloth or fabric under the eyelid; then mark on the eyelid with wax, which should resemble the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary that it be shaped according to the size and elevation of the eyelid: since this now varies among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For there are those who need for a large portion to be cut from the eyelid, according to the amount that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with a needle, find along the two lines that you marked, and start from the greater tear duct down to the lesser tear duct, and let the incision be close to the natural hairs, as thick as the width of a hair.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of the two corners of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then remove the entire piece of tissue.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then sew together the two edges with a needle and fine thread; and wipe away the blood, and make it adhere so that any excess thread does not protrude above the eyebrows, if you wish to do this: and if not, do not worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the stitches and threads for three days or four: after that, take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without stitches and treat it with something that dries and contracts it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid should be raised at the sealing of the wound and its union; but this will be better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of treatment was taught by the ancients to Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is concern for the sick person, and it comes from good practice, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another method used by Ataxmir as well: it involves marking a figure on the eyelid that resembles the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have recounted.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three separate or combined hooks, following the shape shown below, then cut away what is excessive using small forceps, following this shape, with equal precision in the incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	但如果无法使用钩子或无法保持平衡，那么拿一根带有线的针，将其插入形状的中心：再在较大的泪腺附近插入一根线，在较小的泪腺附近插入另一根线：然后用手指均匀地拉紧这些线。
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with an equal elevation: and raise the skin on which the marking is made, as we have recounted.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the wound with stitches: and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	但如果在你的切口或裂口处形成了脓肿，用软膏、类似含有镇静成分的药膏来治疗这个脓肿。
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	有时也会发生睫毛反转的情况。
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, you should use what we mentioned about cutting; but sewing is more artificial for both.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Regarding the treatment of Ataxmir with canes.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And you should turn the eyelid and cut the cleft that is inside, as I have described.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then skillfully make two canes or two thin pieces of wood: their length should be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width should be narrower than the width of a finger: and now cut at the ends of each on both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then attach each one carefully to the part that protrudes from the eyelid, and tightly bind the two canes on both sides with a strong ligature, and leave it for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin that is tightly bound will die, blacken, and decay until it falls off on its own.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If it is delayed, then cut it with forceps.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it has thus consolidated, the eyelid will be raised: and the hairs will not sting.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of the two canes, which you should make according to this figure, and in quantity regarding length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Regarding the raising of stinging hairs in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The procedure is to take a fine needle and insert into it a thin, soft silk thread.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then join the ends together, and tie them tightly with a fine knot: and let the length of the thread be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then arrange another fine thread underneath it briefly, and tie the ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then let the patient place his head in your lap, and be close to the light so that the operation can be clearly seen: for the operation is subtle, or minute.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the lancet with Alinxotati into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate quickly into the eyelid until you withdraw it from above the natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair up over the Alinxotati: and insert that hair into the Alinxotati: if it is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it until the hair comes out with the Alinxotati from the eyelid with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If however the Alinxotati is pulled and the hair does not come out with it: pull the Alinxotati down, with the thread that you arranged in it, until it comes out from the upper opening, and you see it with your eye: then you will pull the Alinxotati and the thread: and remove both, and close the eye: and leave it closed for two days, or three, until the hair adheres to its place, and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either associate with it a long hair from the natural hairs, and let it be pulled out with it: or leave it, until it grows longer over time, and then pull it out.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Concerning the treatment of al-xatrati, which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this al-xatrati occurs in the eye, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this al-xatrati is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	The accidental al-xatrati is caused by the healing of a wound, cutting, cautery, or similar treatments.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of treatment is to cut through that hardened tissue, and to separate its edges, placing between them a bandage made of linen, and binding it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And you should not use drying and constricting substances in its treatment; for if you do that, the al-xatrati will become worse than it was. Instead, use softening substances such as fenugreek: and apply a poultice made with water in which marshmallow root and flax seeds have been cooked: and anoint it with diaquilon ointment, melted with some oil: and wrap it with linen and treat it thus.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the goal of your treatment is to try every means to prevent it from healing, according to its original form.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And the treatment we have described is merely a correction of the al-xatrati, so that it does not return to its original form completely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Concerning the treatment of al-xatrati which occurs in the lower eyelid, and it is a wrinkle or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This is what is done below and is truly called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental occurs from a wound, or a crack, or cautery, and things similar to these.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of the operation is such that you should take a needle with double thread and insert it into the flesh, making it penetrate from the left lacrimal bone to the right lacrimal bone until the thread reaches both extremities of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upwards with the needle, and cut it with a thin blade.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it should, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a rod and place it in the fissure, and use it to turn the eyelid: and make two cuts on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two cuts come from the two corners of the incision, until they meet and form an angle: until when they join, they form this shape, which is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that piece of flesh in the quantity of what is its sharp lower side from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts: or sew them together with thread and wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with what we have said about softening medicines and applications until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if Alxatrati occurs from a crack, and sewing, or cauterization: then it is necessary that you cut the crack flat under the eyelashes, even as it preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with a licinus, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the summary of the discourse on the treatment of Alxatrati, whether it is above or below, is that the procedure should proceed rapidly according to how it is prepared based on the form of Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it itself is of many diversities in form: and the prudent artisan prepares his method in whatever way it is possible for him, until he brings the figure back to its natural form or close to it, and even the sick person himself, according to what befits him from the procedure and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	¶ On the adherence of the eyelid to the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	At times this consolidation occurs in many people such that the upper eyelid becomes adhered to the white of the eye, and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, you must insert the tip of a probe under the eyelid and lift it up: or extend it with a hook. Then cut the adherence with a blunt spatumile, which should not be sharp for cutting but rather dull: so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation and the spatumile does not injure the eye with its sharpness: and make your incision as if you are peeling off that adherence with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the entire adherence is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye and wash it with water: or distill into it from a sieve made of ziniar dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate with a cloth of linen between the eyelid and the eye: and place on the eye wool soaked in egg white: and after three days use a sieve, and with hardeners, until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	Concerning the incision of nails and protruding flesh of the eyelids.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nerve-like: and it is similar to a hard fiber, subtle.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nerve-like, similar to frozen white moisture: which when you touch with iron, or try to grasp it with a hook, it is severed, and the hook does not hold onto it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin except from the larger tear duct, gradually progressing until it covers the vision, and prevents light and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operation in cutting it is: the patient should place his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes and raise the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then grasp the nail with a hook of few folds and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert into it a horsehair or ox hair, or cow hair: and let the thread be strong, and double the tip of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and pierce it with the needle, and tie it with the thread, and extend it upwards: and scrape off with the hair the side of the nail that follows the pupil, as if you were cutting it with the hair to its end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder at the root of the tear duct with a fine scalpel or small forceps: and leave the natural flesh of the tear duct untouched, so that it does not happen from cutting it that there is an uninterrupted flow of tears.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the nail is lifted with just a hook: or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is scraped off with a gentle scalpel, which has this shape.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful that the scalpel does not touch the cornified membrane, so that it does not result in a rupture and the pupil is perforated.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the cut, put some crushed salt or something made from zinc into the eye, and leave it until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with what is necessary until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the nail is not nerve-filled and you cannot insert a needle into it nor does a hook hold in it, then this type of nail is often cured with medicines and heals as I have described in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to cut it, then open the sick person's eye and take a fine, gentle scalpel with weak sharpness, in this shape.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And carefully scrape the nail from above with precision and subtlety.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it becomes thin and breaks apart, and the blade leaves a mark on it, then let drops from your solution made of zinc or red solution, or crushed salt fall into the eye: and treat the eye until another day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat over the operation until everything is completely removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless there is a warm abscess in your eye: then let it be left alone, and treat the abscess until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on it with reason, until it is healed.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	However, if the prominence of the lacrimal flesh causes great harm to the eye, suspend it with a hook and cut a part from it: and do not make the incision too deep, so that the flow of tears is not impaired.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then apply drops to the lacrimal area made of red myrtle, or made from zinc compound, until it is healed.
