¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Concerning the incision of Alguardenic and the flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	A red flesh sometimes grows in the eyes of some people, either composed or placed such that it covers the pupil, approaches it, or stretches over the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outward: and it resembles a rose bud.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the treatment for this condition is such that the patient should place their head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open their eyes and remove that flesh entirely with suitable hooks: and hold it with one forceps or tweezers.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh initially until the entire piece is removed with a scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And be careful around the eye so that you do not injure it during the operation: and let your cut when cutting this flesh be either with a spatulum, as we mentioned in the incision of a nail: or with small forceps, with which dandelion seeds are collected, according to how its shape will appear after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your incision is complete and all the bandage removed, then fill the eye with ground salt: or pour into it powdered red precipitate, and similar medicines that are corrosive: and place over the outer part of the eye a dressing mixed with egg white: to secure it against a hot abscess.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If some of the bandage remains and hot blood dominates you, and you fear a hot abscess: then leave the eye exposed, and treat it with something that soothes the abscess.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the treatment on it until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do likewise with added flesh that occurs in the eye from this condition.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However, it is necessary that you treat any weak eye through either a natural method or an accidental one, operating with iron: and do not intervene with your hand in any of these operations until you see that the member can tolerate such treatment.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	¶ On extracting a thorn from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Thorns are red veins that weave over the eye and prevent vision from functioning properly: and they weaken the eye over time.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore, it is necessary for you first to consider whether the eye in which there is a thorn is strong, and there is no illness in it other than the thorn: then extract the thorn from that eye.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And instruct the patient to place his head in your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with one or two hooks according to your discretion: and let the hook be delicate and double-twisted, in this form, or let there be two hooks gradually in one body, in this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect with fine tweezers those veins with care, and remove the blood hour by hour until you see those veins removed from the eye, and they resolve: and be careful not to injure the eye with the extremities of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your work be at noon in the presence of the sun, and be very resolute in your work: so that you cut only those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then instill into the eye a green or red decoction: so that with its sharpness it may dissolve what remains of the inflammation.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if it is not possible for you to collect all of that at that hour, then apply a plaster to the eye with something that alleviates the pain of the eye: and leave it for several days until the pain subsides: and protect it from a warm abscess: then proceed upon it according to the same method, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the form of the tweezers.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	¶ On the Reduction of the Deviated Nasal Septum.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Doctors name the Deviated Nasal Septum Fistula, which you treat with cauterization or with sharp medicine, depending on its previous course.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no skill in that: except to cut into the abscess near its origin, and extract all the moisture and pus within, until the bone is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is exposed and you see corruption or blackness in it, then scrape it with an instrument whose form is this.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called Rough Head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Make it from smooth iron, and let its head be round like a dirham, which is punctuated with fine points as if by a file or a subtle punch, and place it on the corrupted bone area.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then rotate it between your fingers, and press your hand for a moment until you know that the corruption has been scraped away: do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with drying and astringent medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If the place then consolidates, and flesh grows in it, and the pus flow stops: and after forty days it does not recur, and does not form an abscess, and no accident happens to it: then know that it is healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no other option but to redirect the fistula to the nasal opening, following this method.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is necessary to expose the bone secondly with iron or with a sharp medicine: and when the bone is exposed, then take a drill in this form, with its tip being made of iron and triangular: and its wooden part should be tapered until the end as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it on the bone itself: and let it be near the lacrimal area: and keep your hand a little away from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then rotate your hand with the drill until it penetrates the bone, and let the patient feel it; by this, when the patient holds their hand over their nose, they will feel air coming out.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the place with styptic drying medicines as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When flesh is born and the place hardens, then the substance that was poured outwards returns to its origin; thus it is lighter upon the patient.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the Reduction of an Eyelid Swelling.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye protrudes along with its entire structure, and there is no damage to vision or reduction in size, then you should relax the patient; afterwards, bleed them; then apply cups to the neck without incisions but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then apply a poultice to the eye made from acacia, aloes, frankincense, and styrax.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye above with a plaster covered in many small pieces.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	The method of using the small pieces is as follows: take soft cloths, many of them, and double each cloth over four times; make many such cloths. Then place them one on top of another according to the size needed by the eye. Afterwards, bind them with a hard cloth tightly.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And apply cups with suction without incisions again.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the cups and leave the eye bound day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If the ligature becomes loose again, then it is necessary to bind it tightly once more; then remove the ligature after one day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If you see that the eye has already returned to the eyelid, it is good: and if not, then apply the plaster again, and dusting powders, and tightening, and suction cups, until it is healed.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Concerning the Incision of the Eyelid.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a tear occurs in the eyelid membrane, and it protrudes beyond the eyelids like a grain of sand, disfiguring the appearance of the person due to this condition, and you wish to cut it: then the procedure is as follows, as I describe: You should insert an needle at the base of the eyelid from the lower part to the upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle with double thread from the lacrimal side, and let it penetrate: and release the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the place where the double thread is, and tie it around the eyelid near the needle: and tighten it significantly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then remove the needle, and place a woolen cloth soaked in egg white over the eye: and leave it until the thread falls off with the eyelid.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat the eye with something that strengthens it until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the eyelid is tightened from all sides with a circular bandage made of cloth, until the eye becomes significantly swollen.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then pierce it with a very fine needle that reaches the depth of the eye, and allow the moisture from the egg white to run, and let the eye descend, and immediately begin to tighten it: then continue to tighten it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	Regarding the treatment of Alcomnati.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This illness called Alcomnati is not, in fact, a pus, which accumulates in the eye, similar to water descending, and it is not that itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the method of treatment is to have the patient sit on a prepared seat, either straight or as directed.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take the patient's head with your hands from both sides and move it until you see the pus reach the lower parts of the eye.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then let it be fixed, and do not allow it to descend, and clear the light: and the patient should see things as they were before; and if it does not go down below, know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	但如果脓液没有按照我说的方法下降，那么让患者坐在你的双手之间。
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	然后取一根细探针，在角膜与巩膜连接处的边缘轻轻刺入，直到脓液排出。
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	当脓液排出后，然后滴入温水中混合的蜂蜜水入眼；或在已经煮沸了百里香和蜂蜜的水中滴入。随后按照其余治疗方法进行治疗，直到痊愈。
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	关于眼中流水的治疗，或白内障的治疗。
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	我们现在已经讨论了水的种类在划分中的情况，以及哪些适合通过言语描述和解释来处理，然后根据健康状况采取同样的方法。
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then you must have the sick person sit between your hands, facing away from the light, near the sun: and bind his healthy eye tightly, and then press with your right hand on the eyelid of the eye in which there is water, if it is the left eye; or with your left hand, if it is the right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take with your right hand the almond, if the eye is the left one; or with your left hand, if the eye is the right one.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the tip of the almond near the cornea, by the thickness of a radius where it appears on the white part of the eye near the tear duct: then push the almond with force: and you will turn your hand with it until it penetrates into the whites of the eye: and you will feel that the almond has now reached the empty space.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measure of the almond's journey to its depth be equal to the space that exists from the pupil to the end of the black part: and this is the cornea of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	For you will see it in the very pupil of the eye due to the clarity of the corneal tissue.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the almond until it reaches the place where there is water.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it downward with one force after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If the water descends immediately, then the sick person will see it as soon as their vision opens, and the almond will be in their eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest for a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If the water descends, then place it again second time, except that the almond should come out.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When it is therefore fixed and does not rise: then extract the almond with ease: and you turn your hand gradually.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve something of clear salt in water: and wash the eye with it from within.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place over the eye a poultice of flax or wool infused in rose oil, and egg white: and bind the healthy eye with it.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We, and those of our time, place on it ground cyminum with egg white.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If the almond does not obey you upon entering the eye due to its hardness, since it is made by humans and the person's eye is very hard: then you must take a small spatula, which is called Alberid, whose shape is as follows.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore, use it merely to gently separate the conjunctiva, and do not insert your hand into the opening: and it is only meant to create a narrow passage for the almond.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then insert the almond as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And at the completion of your work, prepare a decently made bedroom for the patient, in which he may sleep on his back in a dark room: and prevent him from all movements and coughing: and give him food that soothes his nature: and do not allow him to move his head either to the right or to the left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the bandage remain in place according to his condition until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then remove it in that dark room and test his vision: and have him look at objects.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligature as far as the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not necessary to do this at the time of treatment or immediately after cutting; rather, it should be done later because water rises quickly due to a strong gaze.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If, however, a hot abscess occurs, then it is necessary to open the eye before the seventh day. And treat it with what soothes the abscess until it is soothed. Then relieve its sight and place over its face an oral device that regulates its vision for several days while they remain in a dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let them leave the house gradually and return to their homes.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that in zalta the student is not exempt from vision exercises; then he becomes bold regarding the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed, one of those who came from Alayrach has told us that a perforated jug was used in Alayrach to draw water.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	Therefore, I have not seen anyone in your land who has done this, nor have I read about it in any of the books of the ancients. It is possible that this is something new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of signs from the jug, so that those who do not know it can stand by them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	They should be made of pure copper: and their extremities should be finely triangular and pointed.
Formae magda.	Forms of the jug.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	Concerning the treatment of flesh growing on the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIIII.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes flesh of various kinds is born in the nose, from which something resembling a many-footed scorpion is produced; and from that there arises a cancerous stone-colored flesh, and from it also arises a soft flesh that is not stone-colored.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	In dealing with the flesh that is soft and not cancerous or fraudulent among those mentioned, you should have the patient sit between your hands facing opposite to the sun, and open their nostrils. Then throw a hook into these flesh growths: then pull them outwards, and cut what you have hooked using a very fine and sharp scalpel from one side until you know that all of the flesh has been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If some of it remains that cannot be cut away, then scrape it with one of the fine instruments with ease until nothing more remains.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If blood overpowers you, or if a warm abscess occurs: then apply what is necessary to counter it. If it is from malignant abscesses, then quickly cauterize it until the blood is cut off and all flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then vinegar, water, or wine should be poured into the nose after the incision.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If the nose is opened and moisture proceeds from it to the palate, then you should know that it is now healed.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If the moisture does not penetrate as it should, then you should know that inside there is flesh born on the upper bones of the nose, to which the instrument did not reach with its incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then it is necessary to insert a linen thread of some thickness, and make many knots in it, and place between each knot the length of a finger or less. The patient should be instructed to send one end of the thread into the nose with a probe or whatever is possible for him after he has made it like azer: and let him pull out his smell, until it reaches as far as the chest and comes out over his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And indeed, this is often done similarly with children in schools like Attom's: and it is an easy thing for one who wishes to do it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place the two ends of the thread, one end that comes out over the nose, and the other that remains inside the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then, as the assistant cuts the flesh at the knots that are in the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is now with the knots of the thread. 
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then remove the thread: and place into the nose after cleaning the blood a linen strip soaked in Egyptian ointment; do this for three days or more, until the ointment has dissolved everything that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then place a lead tube at the end of the treatment in the nose for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	但如果需要干燥的治疗，则使用它。
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	为了制作头部净化装置，用于蒸馏橄榄油和其他鼻用药物，应使用银或铜制成：其形状类似于小型灯，开口像海螺一样：其管道也应类似。
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	而且如果你想制作一个封闭的管子，就像一根管子一样。
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	而且用于制作头部净化装置的海螺形工具应该是完整的，开口的：它应该有一个把手在末端，当你用它加热橄榄油或其他液体药物时可以握住。
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	这就是工具的形状。
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	¶ 关于鼻瘤的治疗。
Caput XXV.	第二十五章。
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	常常在鼻子的末端会长出瘤子，随着时间的推移它会增大并变得更加明显，直到它的外观变得丑陋。
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	对于这种情况，在瘤子刚开始出现时就应该进行切割，并彻底清除它。
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	然后在该位置放置烧灼剂或燃烧性药物，以固定其位置。
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If therefore the incision of it is delayed until it has grown large, then observe, if it is stony, hard, dark in color, and insensitive: then do not touch it with iron; for it is a suppurating sore that is cancerous.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For I have often seen that when one incises such an abscess, it results in great mischief for the one who had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the abscess is soft to the touch, not dark in color, and you see that it can be incised throughout its entirety, then evacuate the patient, and cut it without fear, without hesitation: and treat the area with what dries and constricts until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	¶ On Suturing the Nose, Lip, and Ear.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	Know that when there is a disruption of continuity in one of these cartilages, surgery is of little benefit, except in certain individuals.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when someone sustains an injury from that, you must observe whether it is a recent wound with its own blood, and then bring the edges of the wound together with stitches; subsequently treat it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the edges of a disrupted continuity have already separated and each part has become healthy: then you must remove all parts from the visible skin until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then bring the two edges together with stitches and secure them, and sprinkle powdered dragon's blood and ground frankincense over it; place a piece of soft plaster and another consolidating plaster on top of the powder; and leave it bound for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then loosen it, and replace the medicine: and leave it until the threads come off by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of stitching is to bring together the separated parts, either with needles, as we have described for abdominal sutures: or to bring them together using thread, as I have taught you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	Concerning the removal of nodes from the lips.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people develop hard lumps similar to grain seeds inside their lips, some of which are small and others larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore, you must evert the lip and cut above each node, then hook it with an uncino (hook) and cut it away from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after the cut with powdered zeger (zinc oxide) until the bleeding stops.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then wash it with vinegar, and treat the area with it, where there is astringency, until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	Concerning the incision of flesh that has grown over the gum.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Flesh often grows over the gum, which the ancients called abuluss.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore, you must hook it with an uncino or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root, allowing the pus to drain or the blood to flow.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place on the ground of zegi powder, or other astringent powders.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If that flesh returns after treatment, for it often does return, then cut it a second time, and cauterize it: for it does not return after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	Concerning the treatment of teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes on the surfaces of teeth, from both the inner and outer parts, there gather rough, unpleasant coatings, which can become discolored, turning yellow or green, until the decay spreads to the gums, making the teeth foul because of it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore, you must have the patient sit between your hands, and place their head in your lap. Scrape the molar and tooth where you see coatings that resemble sand, until nothing remains of them. Do the same for black spots, green discolorations, yellowing, and other impurities until they are clean.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If what needs to be removed is taken away from the beginning of the treatment, that is good. If not, then repeat the treatment on them a day later, a second time, and a third time, until finally you achieve your goal through persistent effort.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that a tooth requires scraping with tools of various shapes and forms, as you prepare for the procedure. Therefore, the tool used to scrape the tooth from below is different from the one used between the teeth, according to other forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And you should have these forms of scraping tools prepared, which you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On the Extraction of Tooth Pain.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	One must treat a tooth from its pain with all skill and delay in extracting it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For there is nothing to replace it once it is extracted: for it is a lofty substance. Only when there is no excuse for extracting it should one proceed with extraction when the patient is compelled to do so, in order to stabilize and confirm the painful tooth with you.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	For often the pain deceives the patient, who thinks it is in a particular tooth and extracts it. Then the pain does not subside until the diseased tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we have already seen this from the practice of phlebotomists.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When the painful tooth is confirmed with you, then you must scarify around the tooth with a spatula that has some efficacy until the gums are loosened on all sides: then move it with your fingers or with fine forceps initially gently, until you agitate it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place large forceps properly on it, and have the patient's head between your knees, which you now hold firmly so that it does not move: then pull the tooth in a straight line so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it under the tooth from all sides with ease, and try to move it as you did initially.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is perforated or corroded, then you must fill that hole with cloth and tie it tightly with the tip of a fine probe so that it does not break during the moment of compression on it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And you should act with great care when making incisions around the gums on all sides.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And guard your strength so that you do not break it, and leave part of it behind, and let it return to the patient from the evil which is greater than its initial pain.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And be careful not to do what ignorant bleeders do in their haste and boldness regarding its removal, beyond what we have described.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For they often cause serious illnesses in people, which are difficult to treat, and the roots of the problem remain entirely or partially. Or they extract it along with some bones of the jaw, as we have testified many times before.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then wash the area after its removal with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If bleeding occurs from the area (this often happens), then grind some zegi and fill the area with it. And if you do not have zegi, cauterize it if zegi is not available to you.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The forms of fine forceps used to move a tooth should have long ends, a short handle, and be thick so that they do not bend when pressed against the tooth. The handles should be thick, such that when you squeeze them, they do not slip or bend. They should have short ends and be made of smooth iron or properly forged steel with straight ends: and on their ends there should be teeth, some of which fit into others to grip firmly by constriction.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes the ends are shaped like the beak of a bird called a heron, and they provide a strong grip.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the removal of teeth, and the extraction of broken jawbones.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When some of the tooth that is being removed breaks and remains, then you should place a cloth soaked in butter on the site for one or two days until it softens. Then insert into it an instrument shaped like the beak of a bird called a heron, or use forceps.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The shape of these forceps is as follows.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their tips should be made like the inside of a file: or like an aliskilfegi.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If these forceps do not suffice for the extraction, then you should hollow out around the root, expose all the flesh, and insert an instrument called a small Lever, which has this shape.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	The tip should be short and somewhat thick: and it should not be too flexible so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root comes out with this tool, it is good: and if not, you should assist with these other instruments whose shapes are as follows.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The shape of the first instrument has a triangular tip, with some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The shape of the triangular tip is fine and slender.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	Also, you should use this instrument with two branches, which has this shape.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools that have been mentioned earlier concerning teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	Also, let the aid be with this instrument which resembles a large hooked shape, of this form, with a triangular end twisted, in which there is something thickened, so that it does not break: and let it not be absorbent.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And you should know that there are many instruments for teeth: and likewise the rest of the instruments are not counted, and a prudent artisan, subtle in his art, finds by himself an instrument according to what the operation signifies to him and the ailments themselves.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because there are ailments for which the ancients did not mention instruments, due to the diversity of their forms.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, a bone from the jaw or from other bones of the mouth breaks, or rots: then examine it carefully in its place with what is suitable for it among the instruments and forceps that I mentioned for extracting roots, and assist with gestures, whose form is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let there be something thickened gradually to draw it out or hold the bone with it, so that it does not retreat and go away until the bone comes out: and restore the place with medicines suitable for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there is only a small rot in the bone, then scrape it from the rotten part, and treat it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Regarding the cutting of prominent teeth that rise above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XXXII.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth rise prominently not according to their natural course, it makes the appearance ugly because of this, especially when it happens to women and girls, namely those who engage in prostitution.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore, you should consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if a tooth is born after another tooth and does not fit, nor can it be filed or smoothed: then remove it. And if it is connected to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument, which has the following form.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small beak and is made of iron, with a very sharp tip.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And the cut you make to cut it should be done over several days, and due to the hardness of the tooth, and so that another tooth is not dislodged.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it protrudes and is exposed to filing: then file it with an iron file, which has this form.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let it be entirely of iron, and its handle should consist of fine points, like a file used to make needles. With this, the tooth should be filed gradually over several days easily, so that the tooth is not dislodged and falls out; then smooth it, finally scrape it with some razors.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If a tooth is fractured in such a way that it injures the tongue: then you must file it as well, until the roughness of the fracture is removed and it is evened out: and smoothed, so that it does not injure the tongue nor impair speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	Concerning the repair of teeth with gold wire.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the front teeth suffer from concussion and movement due to impact or accident, and the patient cannot bite on them without causing them to fall out: and you have treated them with astringent medicines but it was ineffective: then there is a method to secure them with gold wire: for silver turns green and deteriorates over time, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the thread be of medium fineness and thickness according to its quantity, so that it may fit between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	The form of the procedure is such that you should take a thread and insert twice its length between two healthy teeth; then weave with both ends of the thread between the moving teeth, whether one or several, until you reach the healthy tooth on the other side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the weaving back to the part where you began: and tighten your hand with subtlety and wisdom until it cannot be removed at all: and let your binding when tightening the thread be near the roots of the teeth so that it does not slip out.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut the excess thread ends with tweezers: and join them together, and turn them as you move: and hide them between the healthy tooth and the moving tooth so that they do not irritate the tongue: then let it remain tightly bound as long as necessary.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	But if it loosens or breaks, tie them with another thread, and it will remain stable in this way for the entire time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the form of the teeth, and the figure of the weaving of two healthy teeth and two moving teeth, as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one tooth or two return to their places after an injury, and are retained as we have described, and remain: and this is done only by a skilled and experienced artisan.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes a piece of bone from an animal is shaped: and it is made to fit the form of a tooth, and placed in its place, where it supports the tooth and is secured, as we have said: and it remains, and serves for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Of cutting the ligament that occurs under the tongue, and prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIIII.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament that occurs under the tongue is either natural, with which a person is born, or accidental, from a wound that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the procedure is to open the mouth of the patient at the head in your lap, and raise their tongue: then cut that nerve-like ligament horizontally until the tongue is freed from its restriction.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is something hard and knotted in it, and this is due to the healing of a wound: then apply a hook to it, and cut it horizontally until you sever the ligament and release the knot.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And be careful that there is no split deep in the flesh, and that you do not cut an artery there, causing a loss of blood.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then cleanse the area of the incision with rose water, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place a linen bandage under the tongue that the patient should hold throughout the night: so that it does not heal too quickly.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If however bleeding occurs, then apply crushed zechar (a type of plant) to the wound.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If the blood overpowers you, then cauterize the area with a speckled cautery, which is appropriate for it: then treat it with the remaining methods of care until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	Of extracting a ranula which occurs under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Sometimes an abscess occurs under the tongue that resembles a small frog, preventing the tongue from its natural function: and it may grow so large as to fill the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the procedure is to open the patient's mouth facing the sun: and examine the abscess.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If you see that it is of a dark color, or black, hard, and the patient has no feeling in it: then do not touch it, for it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it tends toward whiteness, with moisture present, then attach a hook to it, and cut it with a sharp knife, and free it from all parts.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If the blood overpowers you during your time of operation, then apply crushed zeig on it until the bleeding stops: then return to your operation until you remove it completely.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then wash it with vinegar and salt: and treat it with appropriate care until it is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	¶ On the treatment of an abscess in the tonsils.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes there occur between the throat glands, which resemble almond-like nodes that appear externally: and they are called the tonsils. When you treat them as we have said in the division, and they do not heal, then examine them carefully.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If the abscess is hard, dark in color, and has little feeling: then do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is of a red color and its root is thick: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood; rather leave it until it becomes ripe.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either you will pierce it: or it will break on its own.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is of a white color, round, and its root is delicate: then it must be cut.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the procedure to be followed is that you should observe before operating whether the swelling has become quiet and warm in its completeness, or if it has decreased somewhat: then have the patient sit facing the sun, and place his head in your lap: open his mouth, and let the assistant take between his hands an instrument whose form is as follows, and press the patient's tongue with it below.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	It should be made of silver or copper, and it should be thin like a small knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you press with it on the tongue and the swelling becomes visible to you, and your sight falls upon it: then take a hook and fix it in the tonsil, and pull it out as far as you can, except that you also draw something from the surrounding tissues with it.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it with an instrument whose form is as follows.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It resembles forceps: however, its ends should be curved, such that the opening of each is directly opposite the other at an angle: therefore, make sure it is made of polished iron or brass.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	但如果手头没有这种器械，那么就用剪刀来切割，其形状如下。
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Let it be sharp on one side, not sharp on the other side.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you cut one almond-shaped area, cut the other following the same kind of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision, the patient should gargle with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if blood flow occurs, the patient should gargle with water in which bark of pimento trees has been boiled: or myrtle leaves, and similar astringents, until the blood flow stops: then treat it until it heals.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes other abscesses arise in the throat besides the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Cut them accordingly as I said regarding the incision of the two tonsils, equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I have indeed already treated a woman who had an abscess that had arisen between her throat, which was causing darkening of the complexion, loss of senses, and was nearly closing off her throat: the woman was breathing through a narrow passage, and food and water intake were already prohibited for her: she had reached the point of death if it had remained untreated for one or two more days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the abscess had risen so much that it extended two branches until they emerged above the two nasal openings.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	I hurried quickly and hooked one of them with an instrument.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out, and a large portion was removed from it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut it where it could be grasped through the nasal opening.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did that for him which protruded from the nostril on the other side.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened his mouth and pressed his tongue. After that, I fixed a hook into the abscess. Then I removed part of it, and only a little blood came out. Thus, the throat of the woman was cleared, and she began to drink water immediately, then she started to eat as well.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	So I did not stop cutting from that abscess many times over a long period: and the abscess would grow back in place of what I had cut, until it became too prolonged with it.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	Therefore, I devised a way and cauterized the abscess between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	She thus abstained from additions: then I walked away on my part, and did not know what God did for her after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	Concerning the cutting of an abscess on the throat.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When catarrh descends to the throat and forms an abscess, and it is long, then it is called vertical. And if it is thick and round at the lower part, then it is called a berry.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is treated as we said in the division, and the treatment does not help: and you see that the hot abscess has subsided from it, and it is subtle: then you must cut it.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And if what is aggregated from it is round and does not have length, and is of a blood-colored or dark hue, and has no sensation: then you must avoid cutting it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For there is fear upon the sick person.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore, when you see it according to the method I described, by its whiteness and length, make the sick person sit before the sun; and press his tongue with the instrument which was previously mentioned: then place the hook in it and pull it down; and cut it with one of the two instruments that I mentioned for cutting the two tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And you should not cut from it except what is added beyond the natural boundary without any addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut from it more than necessary, you will harm the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the cutting, use what we have described for the cutting of the two tonsils: and take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the patient is afraid of the cutting, then you should use ingenuity in cauterizing it without fear and without causing terror.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the method of cauterizing it is not done except with sharp water: and you should place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press his tongue with the instrument that I mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take some of the water that I told you about in the chapter on cauterizing, and apply it to a coal that is not extinguished, and place it neither thick nor thin, and fill the concavity of this instrument, which has the following form.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let the extremity of it where the medicine is placed be concave, like the bowl of a spoon.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on the wound itself: and let the patient lie on his side so that saliva runs from his mouth due to the intrinsic nature of the medicine, so that nothing from it descends into his throat and harms him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you should apply it to the wound in the amount of half an hour until you see it turning black and the pain subsiding due to the medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take a rag, and wrap it around the end of a rod, and pour medicine onto the rag, and insert the rod with the rag into a tube from above, until the rag adheres to the wound.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this multiple times until you achieve what you desire from cauterizing the wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then leave it: it will dry up and fall off after three days or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you need to repeat the treatment with medicine, do so: and after cauterization, clean around the wound with a rag soaked in butter, and purify what is around it with the medicine: and wash it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And treat it externally with applications and internally with gargles until it is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This method of treatment is therefore healthier than cutting and more distant from the risk of fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And at times the wound is also treated with something subtler than cauterization and cutting: it is treated with fumigation, in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take a leek, hyssop, origany, rue, cumin, chamomile, southernwood, and similar herbs; and mix all of them or some of them in a pot, and let them be submerged with vinegar and boiled: and the pot should be sealed with clay appropriately: and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot above which place an instrument concave according to this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Make it of silver or copper: and insert the end where there is a grenade into the patient's mouth until vapor rises up to the cloth on top of the tube, until the cloth becomes very dark.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat this process multiple times until it dries.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful not to perform this treatment at the beginning of the abscess's onset.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For it usually adds to the abscess: and you should not do this unless the abscess is beginning to show signs of heat.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not available to you, then take a tube and attach a piece of cork at the end so that it does not burn the patient's mouth: for the cork prevents the vapor from burning the mouth: and this is part of good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	Concerning the removal of spines and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often an object such as a fish bone or spine, or something similar, adheres to the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore, you should remove what is apparent above and visible after pressing the tongue with an instrument near a light source, so that it becomes clear to you what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, you must have the sick person vomit before the food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps what is attached will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Let the sick person swallow a piece of turnip, or the root of lettuce, or a bite of dry bread; or let them take a small piece of dry sea sponge and tie it to a thread, then let them swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it reaches the place where there are spines or bones, and it is extracted, then it comes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If it does not come out with what we have mentioned, then use an instrument made of lead in the following form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a radius for a little while, and at its end let there be a curvature, which he should insert into his throat with ease: and he should keep his head raised upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And he should be careful not to touch his epiglottis, so that it does not cause him to cough and push out with it the bone or spine, or the physician should insert it himself with his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	However, it is better for the sick person to insert it, due to his knowledge of the location of the attached object: and he should push it downward, or pull his hand with the instrument upward, all of this according to the quantity that is prepared for him, until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Concerning the Removal of a Leech.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the leech is treated with what I said in the division about treatment with medicines and it does not help, then examine the throat of the patient in front of sunlight, or near the sun after pressing their tongue with the instrument that I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon a leech, remove it with a small hook or with fine forceps properly.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible with them, then take a hollow tube and insert it into the throat of the patient up to near the throat: then insert into the hollow of the tube a glowing iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this multiple times: and let the patient abstain from water for the entire day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a vessel filled with cold water and open his mouth in it: and rinse his mouth with it, and do not swallow any of it: and stir the water one hour after another with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For when the leech feels the water, it falls immediately.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If, however, it does not come out as we have described, then fumigate the patient with crushed flies, or with wormwood with the instrument that I described for vulvar fumigation.
