Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of this bloodletting is such that the patient should compress their neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold their nose with your left hand, and take a fine, long bloodletting instrument, and place it in the middle of the nasal septum.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vein is not visible to the eye there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary to keep your hand with the bloodletting instrument for a short while: and let the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it for one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is quickly restored.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On Phlebotomy of the Veins Guidegi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	However, the phlebotomy of the two veins Guidegi is helpful for constriction of breathlessness, and for the onset of leprosy, and for melancholic ailments, and for impetigo and bad ulcers, and for corrosive conditions, that is, herps and eczema.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the procedure for their phlebotomy is that the patient should hold both sides of his neck with a bandage; and the practitioner should stand over the head of the patient, who sits on a chair.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then, when phlebotomizing the vein, make the incision somewhat long.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out a moderate amount of blood, or according to what you see is necessary for the condition.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterward, remove the bandage and apply moderate pressure to both veins with a dressing, so that the patient does not suffocate.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And leave the patient until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On Phlebotomy of the Veins Algeberich.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The phlebotomy of the veins Algeberich is helpful because it benefits conditions such as mouth sores, gum corruption: and bad ulcers: and cracks in the lips, and bad ulcers, even those that are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of bleeding them is such that you should seat the patient before you and bind their neck with a strap.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn up the lip and look at two veins: one on the right side of the lip and the other on the left; the location of each is indicated by their dark color.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true, because around them are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore, cut both with an oblique incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if you are in doubt and do not know which one to use, then pay attention to the larger of the incisions, and the more prominent of them will be apparent.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly, do this for the two veins that are on the upper lip; customarily, it is most common to cut the two veins that are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Regarding bleeding the vein under the tongue after the cephalic bloodletting.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The benefit of bleeding the two veins under the tongue is that cephalic bloodletting is helpful for suffocations in the throat, inflammation of the gums, and illnesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of bleeding them is such that you should seat the patient between your hands before sunlight; lift their tongue and look under it on one side for a vein, and on the other side for another vein; the color of each tends toward blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore, bleed both veins; and be careful not to go too far with your hand while bleeding them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under it are arteries, and perhaps there will be a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Concerning the Three Veins in the Elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins which are bled in the elbow are those whose bleeding has become customary practice for all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And the bleeding of these veins is performed according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by puncturing with a broad myrtle bleeding instrument, or with an olive one for fineness; or by cutting with a small knife bleeding instrument, which is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Such is Alnesil, which is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these, there are broad and fine types according to the width of the veins and their constriction. The form of the myrtle bleeding instrument is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening concave, full, protruding, visible, thick veins, and those that contain thick, cloudy blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this bleeding instrument is of lesser width and finer at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for bleeding fine veins that contain thin, yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Concerning the Bleeding of the Basilic Vein.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The basilic vein, which is one of these three veins, is beneficial for bleeding.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Since it extracts blood from ailments that are under the throat and neck, which extend to the chest and abdomen. It is fitting for a person who practices phlebotomy to be cautious with this vein, as there is an artery underneath it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he makes a mistake and adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will cut that artery, and it will result in a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, it is necessary not to use a sharp phlebotomy instrument on this vein; rather, one should use a cutting instrument like an Alnasil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the basilica vein does not appear clearly, then it is necessary to move away from it and switch to another vein, or find a branch of it; or you may perform phlebotomy on the Funem brachii instead.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is clear, and cut it with a phlebotomy instrument like an Alnesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform phlebotomy on it, then before compressing the arm, touch the area until you recognize the location of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the spot with a hot iron, then compress the arm, and cut the vein with a concave incision using a phlebotomy instrument like an Alnesil, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And be careful that the incision does not fall in the space between the location of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see that as you compress the area with a ligature, there is swelling at the spot marked with a hot iron, then that swelling is due to the artery. Therefore, avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see the blood at phlebotomy rising like a boy's urine, and it is fine and red: then know that it comes from an arterial blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then hurry and place your finger on it for a long space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore the blood is cut off (for often it is cut off), then compress the arm, and let it be: and the patient should guard against moving it: and let him be cautious of fear regarding it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for several days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not stop and overcomes you: and there is no medicine available to you at that moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities contract, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the husk of a date, and burn it: take one half, and apply it to the site of the vein constriction with a bandage and powders until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then treat it with what was mentioned earlier from the place of powders that stop the flow of blood: and stopping the blood is not difficult in most cases, due to the small size of the wound and the possibility of applying a bandage from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Concerning Phlebotomy of the Blue Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	Phlebotomy of the Blue Vein is beneficial for drawing blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because it is composed of the branch of the Basilic vein and the branch of the Cephalic vein, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting for the phlebotomist to be above her so that he need not fear from the phlebotomy of her, for under her is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy and finds a nerve, it results in numbness in that area, and healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it does not heal completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If, however, it is hidden in some people and is subtle and does not appear: then you should place your phlebotomy where you perform it, with a section using Alnesil, and avoid the nerve with all your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Concerning the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein is beneficial because it draws blood from the head and aids in ailments of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is proper for this vein, if you wish to perform phlebotomy on it, to do so by puncturing with a olive phlebotomist or a myrtle phlebotomist: because it is safer than all other veins, since there is no superficial artery nor nerve beneath it.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, it is fitting for you during phlebotomy to avoid the head of the vein with the phlebotomist slightly, and seek a softer spot: and it does no harm if it is not found upon the first percussion, but rather repeated several times with the phlebotomy.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, it may abscess in some people when they are not bled during the first percussion, but such an abscess does no harm to them.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the Utility of Bloodletting and Precautions to be Observed in It.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of bloodletting and the circumstances arising from it, which you must consider for its proper execution.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First of all, you should know that bloodletting is administered only for the preservation of health, its maintenance, and as a precaution against the onset of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And for bloodletting to be performed on one of the three veins in the elbow, namely the Cephalic, the Fusca, and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And for bloodletting to be performed at the beginning of Spring after fasting, and in summer: and in autumn and winter after eating, when signs of fullness are apparent.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And bloodletting should be performed on the first day, or on the third day, after three hours have passed since dawn.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Bloodletting administered for illnesses does not have a fixed time; it should be performed when circumstances and necessity require it, whether day or night, and at any hour and in any season.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not appropriate to bloodlet children until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	A pregnant woman should not be bloodlet unless from the fourth month until the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	And elderly people who have passed sixty years of age should not be bloodlet.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	Therefore, when someone wishes to have bloodletting for any reason, it is necessary that they cleanse their bowels before bloodletting with a gentle enema, if there is much retained feces in them: so that the veins near the bloodletting site do not attract harmful putrid excesses from the bowels to the principal limbs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	The patient should not be bloodlet when they are stuffed, that is, have a nausea-inducing fullness; nor after being drunk, until such conditions are removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor should an ill person with dropsy be bloodlet.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And bloodletting should be avoided again after colic pain, vomiting, and diarrhea, and after excessive sexual activity, labor, exercise, wakefulness, fasting, and anything that dissipates strength from the bodily or vital substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors before doing it, if the blood is thick due to food and drinks, and medicines: if it is possible for him to do that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then enter a bath, if nothing prohibits it: or engage in some exercise, to make the blood thinner.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the bloodletting for him in the chest area, around the third day, as we have said: and strive to ensure that his chest is evacuated on that day of all harmful animal accidents: such as constriction, anger, and fear: and of all bodily accidents, such as labor, pain, excessive sweating, and similar conditions.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let the objects that are usually used by people because of their aromatic properties, scent, joy, and similar qualities be present at his seat in a quantity as is possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then the phlebotomist should sit on a raised cushion, which is higher than the usual phlebotomy cushion; afterwards, he should extend his arm and rub it twice or three times with his hand.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tie the vein with a strap and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And the compression should be moderate, for when it is uneven, or too tight in the binding, then it prevents the flow of blood; or if it is too loose, then it also impedes the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the compression, it is necessary that the person to be phlebotomized rub their hands together simultaneously until the veins become swollen and clearly visible.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist should clean the site to be phlebotomized with a little oil, specifically an old oil.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then place the index finger of the left hand on the vein slightly above where he wants to perform the phlebotomy, so that the vein does not slip away and ensure a steady puncture.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because the veins are like a fleeing string at the time of phlebotomy; and they are also full of airiness: and when you place the lancet on them, they contract under the lancet, deceiving the phlebotomist, and do not open for the lancet: and if it does open them, it is constricted. Therefore, it is necessary that the phlebotomist be firm and attentive to all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then put down the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If the vein opens on the first attempt, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat it another time below that place a little, or above it with haste: unless the area becomes abscessed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it becomes abscessed, or the patient grows worse, then leave it for a day, or two days: and do not tighten the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For perhaps it will attract a warm abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Nor should he enter a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if desired.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the incision is small, or the blood flows gently: and you fear that the quantity of blood you wish will not come out: then repeat the phlebotomy at the hole itself along its straightness, and add a little to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with haste before the area becomes abscessed, for an abscessed area often occurs in many people during a minor procedure.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that it is already abscessed, then do not repeat the procedure on it at all, for it will not benefit you to do so.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something from olive oil residue on it: for it alleviates the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this case than the oil itself and other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly apply oil residue in all your phlebotomies where you ligate the veins to restrict blood flow: and this is done with either tyrian cerate or sage ointment, when applied to the site.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood becomes refined and dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If a large abscess occurs at the site of phlebotomy, which often happens, especially for those who are not regularly bled or whose vein incision is small, then quickly apply a sponge soaked in warm water and salt to the area, and keep it bound for one hour, as this helps to dissolve it.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary to do this after the blood has been drawn from the vein completely, either from that vein or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If there remains a black or green discoloration at the site after some days, it is not harmful. And if you wish, apply aloes, or dissolved myrrh, or something from mint juice, that is, calamint or something similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And abscesses and swellings often occur around the phlebotomy site at the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Place your hand on the site, then if you find softness upon pressing it, then that swelling is harmful.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Be careful, therefore, not to apply anything from what we have mentioned to it.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from an artery there.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But apply a plaster to it with something that has astringent properties to harden the area.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it along with the rest of the care until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to extract blood from every person in accordance with the extent of their vitality.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from a reddish color prevailing over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it be allowed to exit until it becomes red; and similarly, if you see it as thick, then let it be allowed to exit until it becomes thin; and similarly, if it is acute, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for one who is full, strong, and requires bloodletting, that the incision of the vein be enlarged, and let it be lateral; and in the case of one who is weak, let it be contrary to this.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he extracts it in stages, and that the opening be narrow: and what is better administered during bloodletting is a transverse cut, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of bloodletting is safe from the excessive flow of blood and from cutting the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy and safer than bloodletting by length and width.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And for those who are prone to fainting during bloodletting, it is necessary that they eat a little bread infused in pomegranate syrup before bloodletting: or scallion stew if it is heated: and extract blood from them in three stages, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if they have a cold complexion, then let them take bread infused in murri syrup before bloodletting: or in aromatic honey syrup with spices, or in fragrant aromatic syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	And if fainting occurs during bloodletting and the cause is excessive loss of blood, then it is necessary that they drink water from meat and fine fragrant syrup: and use aromatics with vinegar, and anoint their chest with it: and use other remedies which we have mentioned in the division on fainting caused by evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	He who wishes to let his arm and release his blood gradually: it is necessary for him whose venesection is for the purpose of a large evacuation, and whose strength is weak, to release his blood little by little according to the measure of his strength over consecutive days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	He who wishes to let his arm and release his blood the second time, and whose body is strong: then he should do so seven or nine hours after his first venesection.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	He who wishes to draw blood from his body towards the opposite side to which it inclines: he should be bled on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In the body of him in whom there is already much heated blood that has become acrid and causes fever to occur: it is necessary for the blood to exit from him all at once, and a large quantity should be drawn out: and the incision should be enlarged until fainting occurs; after which you must maintain all conditions of venesection: and place your hand on his pulse near the flow of blood, so that death does not occur instead of fainting.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For this often happens when the phlebotaomer is ignorant and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not appropriate when you wish to let the arm and release blood a second time, if the vein orifice is already closed and the exit of blood becomes difficult, to press on it forcefully and quickly straighten out any curvature.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is very bad; indeed, leave it until the second venesection.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with care what has coagulated from the blood in the vein orifice and place something dissolved salt in water upon it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place on it something from Tyrian ointment of Alfarach or Sagzena, and apply it with gentle compression until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if the vein is already an abscess, then leave it open and do not cover it until the abscess subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity requires drawing blood a second time and there is no excuse to avoid it, then either use the phlebotomy instrument on that same spot again or do it on another vein in the other arm.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The vein of the arm is phlebotomized in the place of Fuscae and Basilicae when they are not found, since it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that the patient should immerse his hand in warm water until it turns red and the vein becomes clearly visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then bind it above with a ligature of moderate tightness in the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then make the incision gradually across the vein, neither too wide nor along its length: let the cut be somewhat large, and when you perform the phlebotomy, do it for a short time over the joint of the hand.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the flow of blood is obstructed, then immerse your hand again in warm water and let the blood run into the water until you achieve your goal.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if it is during the summer days, then you are excused from immersing your hand again in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And the flow of blood into warm water is greatest during the winter season.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is safer than all other veins, since there is no pulsating vein beneath it, nor any nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	But the phlebotomy of the right hand of Saluatus causes diseases of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is such that you should compress the hand with a ligature, or with your hand, after you introduce it into warm water, until the vein swells and becomes clearly visible.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then phlebotomize it acrosswise.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, it will not harm it in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And keep it so that you do not use your hand with the phlebotomy tool.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For beneath it are the naked nerves of the fingers from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then return the hand to warm water, and let the blood flow from it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not return it to warm water, the blood will coagulate in the vein opening and hinder its flow.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have thus extracted from the blood the required amount, then apply oil and salt to the vein: so that it does not heal too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly, you should do this with every branch that is cut.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The phlebotomy from the left hand is for treating diseases of the spleen. And similarly, perform the phlebotomy on it as you did with the previous one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	However, phlebotomy of the great saphene veins is beneficial for diseases in the lower part of the body, such as diseases of the womb, and retention of menstruation, and kidney ailments, and old sores on the thighs and legs, and similar illnesses.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the method of phlebotomy is such that the patient should immerse his foot in hot water: and apply rubbing to it until the veins swell: and tie above the joint of the foot with a tourniquet.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the vein is located near the heel, appearing towards the big toe: and many branches extend from it on the surface of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, the phlebotomist should cut the vein at its larger branch or near the heel where it gathers: for it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you perform phlebotomy on the surface of the foot, then be careful not to cut the nerves that lie beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And when you perform the phlebotomy where you cut it across, as if you want to sever it: and let the phlebotomy be neat.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the outflow of blood is prevented, then immerse his foot again in hot water: and let the blood flow into it until it is emptied.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the phlebotomist misses the vein on the first attempt, then repeat the phlebotomy slightly higher up, for that location is safe, and you need not fear harm from it when you are careful of the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And do the same with the great saphene vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the sciatic veins, as we said, is near the heel on the outer side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the remedy for phlebotomy of it is, to relieve pain in the ankle, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the procedure for phlebotomy of it is that the patient should enter a bath and hurry; bind his leg from the side of the ankle up to four fingers above the heel with a thin, long strip of cloth: it does not show unless because of this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it therefore appears, then let the phlebotomist cut it according to whatever method is possible for you, either across: and it is better, either by cutting it with an incision or by cutting it with a knife.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is safer, and it is very hidden in most people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the senses: then let the phlebotomist cut some branch of it, and that is which appears on the back of the foot towards the heel: and be careful of the nerves, and let the blood flow in the quantity that you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the binding, and place leather over the site of the phlebotomy, and bind the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It is quickly healed.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	¶ On Venesection, and the Quality of Its Use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XC VIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Venesection instruments are made from horns, and from metal, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And ventosity is performed in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification and bloodletting; the other is ventosity without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventosity which is performed without scarification is in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is done with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventosities that are administered with scarification and bloodletting are fourteen places on the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	One of these is Ventosatio Alnocrati, which is at the back of the head; and Alkehel, which is in the middle of the neck; and the ventosae Alhagdahim, which are two plates on both sides of the neck simultaneously; and ventosae menti, which is under the chin below the mouth; and ventosae of the two spatulas: and ventosae Alachosos at the end of the tail; and ventosae of the two armpits, which are in the middle of both arms; and ventosae of the two thighs; and ventosae of the two ankles.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And ventosity indeed does not draw blood from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of this, their efficacy does not diminish as it would with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor should ventosity, whether with fire or without fire, be administered in any diseases caused by congestion until the entire body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity prompts ventosity due to illness or habit, we administer it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at the end of it, and in the middle, whenever it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	Which is to say, there are people who, when the blood multiplies within them to the point where it needs to be extracted by phlebotomy, find that they have a swelling in their head and a headache.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them are those who find their face, head, and neck filled with fullness and redness.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And among them are those who experience itching on their face and forehead, as well as darkness and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And among them are those who scratch the site of their phlebotomy.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose laughter increases.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And among them is one who tastes blood in their mouth: or their tongue becomes sore and spits out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose sleep increases.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And among them is one who sees blood and redness, and the slain, and wounds, and things similar to these in their sleep.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we observe any of these symptoms, and especially if they occur on the fifteenth day of the month: we then order phlebotomy to be performed two or three hours after their appearance.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The phlebotomy of the neck is helpful because it relieves heaviness in the head and what is discharged goes to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	However, it should be performed after the complete evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this phlebotomy of the neck serves as a substitute for head phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted for one who has a cold constitution or suffers from catarrh to use it.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it causes him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And for that reason, it is not appropriate for the elderly or those suffering from cold headaches to use it.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	However, one who becomes habitually dependent on it will generate forgetfulness.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for that reason, you should instruct the Leecher to remove their hand with the suction cup temporarily and direct it downwards, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Venesection or Alkehel is used in place of dark venesection and basilic venesection, and for that reason it benefits those with asthma, constriction of breath, rupture of the breathing apparatus, cough, and fullness.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary to apply the Alkehel suction cup temporarily, for if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	However, venesection alhagdahim benefits pains and accidents in the head, ophthalmia, migraine, perforation, and pain at the roots of teeth: and it is used in place of basilic venesection.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should instruct the Leecher not to press their hand with incisions: so as not to cut an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	However, venesection below the chin benefits alcohol-related problems in the mouth, corruption of the gums, and similar illnesses that are in the mouth: and it is used in place of alieherich venesection, which is on both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The manipulation of spatulas, which is applied to the alchafacha, is done through flexion and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The application of suction to the internal parts of the two fossae provides assistance for phlebotomy of the three veins: Basilica, Fusa, and Cephalica. For it attracts blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh; and these small veins draw from other larger veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And you must instruct the person applying suction not to proceed too far with the incisions: for the area is exposed and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The suction applied above the alchausos benefits hemorrhoids and anal ulcers, as well as lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you must instruct the person applying suction to use a large suction cup made of air, because the area requires strong suction, and perhaps finer suction cups may break. The incision should also be deep.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The suction applied to the legs clearly reduces swelling, for it draws blood from throughout the body and relieves old pains in the kidneys, uterus, and bladder. It also induces menstruation and aids in bothor and ademenul: and it serves as a substitute for phlebotomy of the two saphena veins and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body greatly and cause syncope in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the benefit of suction applied to the alhorcobeni is similar to the benefit of suction applied to the two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of bloodletting is such that you should place the lancet first and suck with a moderate suction; do not prolong the position of bloodletting but place them quickly and remove them quickly so that the humors come to the place equally by arrival: do not cease to repeat this and continue until you see the area reddened and swollen, and the redness of the blood becomes apparent. Then scarify and proceed with suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the condition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For those with tender flesh and few pores, you should scarify them once only, not more, so that the area does not become ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And instruct the bloodletter to enlarge the incisions slightly and to go deep a little: and to moderate the suction in ease, speed, and with gentle movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is thickness in the blood, then you should scarify twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	Indeed, in the first instance, an opening is created for the refinement of the blood and its watery part: and in the second instance, for a thorough extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is very impure, then a third scarification should be performed: to achieve the final result.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we wish to extract the blood gradually or for a short while, one scarification is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to extract a large amount of blood, we should perform multiple scarifications.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure and find that the blood is thick, then it is necessary to scarify deeply: and the equal limit in scarification is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What should be administered from oils in the treatment of wounds, and what one must beware of when treating wounds.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In the case of one whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and whose pores are tight, it is necessary to anoint the wounded areas with oils that are penetrating, soothing, and resolving: if it is in the summer season, such as oil of alexipharmic plants, or violet oil, or sweet almond oil, or oil from pumpkin seeds.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the winter season, then use narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or saracen oil: and similar oils.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	But if the exudate is thick and cold, then use gentian oil, or oil of balsamite, or aleovent oil, or anise oil: and similar oils.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	But if the wound has large pores and tender flesh, then it is necessary to avoid oils, and these wounds should be washed with rose water, or cold water, or distilled water, or pumpkin water, or purslane water: and similar waters.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood has much humidity should wash the wounds with vinegar, or water of myrtle, and sumac: and similar substances.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	He whose exudates are thick should wash his wounds with old wine, or water of pennyroyal, or a decoction of anise, or chamomile: and similar substances.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary to be cautious about performing wound treatment in a bath or immediately after stepping out of the bath; rather, it should be administered one hour, or even two hours, after exiting the bath.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary for anyone to sleep after vomiting.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is the proper procedure for regulating Ventosandus or Phlebotomatus before vomiting?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after it, one must first consider: if the Ventosatus or Phlebotomatus is choleric and the sharpness and inflammation overcome his blood: then he should take cooling substances, such as pomegranate seeds: and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and scammony, and julep: and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And place for his food tender meats, and mutton well cooked, and seasoned foods with herbs: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And for one whose complexion is cold, it is necessary that he drink syrup made of honey, or amber, or scammony made from seeds: and let him drink moderately aged wine, which is between old and new: and he should be instructed to eat sparingly.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And place for his food tender meats, and young rabbits: and sparrows, that is, small birds: and squabs of doves should be served.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink on the day of vomiting and bloodletting be more than the food: and it is necessary to give in drink for some people at certain times theriac alfaroch, or a medicine made from musk, that is, nutmeg, or alecost before vomiting: and before bloodletting, or after: to strengthen the principal limbs, and to refine the blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not necessary for them to take it in warm drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	Of Flatulence Without Incision.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Flatulence that does not require incision occurs in cases involving the bladder, spleen, gout, and areas of the abdomen, navel, and regions near the kidneys; for these parts do not tolerate incisions.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And these conditions are sought only when there is an attack of blood from one part to another, such as when we apply flatulence to the breasts in a condition involving bleeding from the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to remove cold and unboiled flatulence from one part by applying it to another, such as when we apply flatulence to the abdomen and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it rarefies the part, warms it, and removes pain because it resolves that flatulence.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also applied to the kidneys when there is obstruction or stone formation in them.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For by the power of its attractive force, it may open obstructions or remove stones from their place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly, it does this when applied to the bladder and spleen to expel flatulence from both of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these flatulence treatments are administered empty with a cut only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And at times they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And at times they are administered filled with warm water in cases of pleurisy: and this is done by filling the flatulence vessel with hot water alone, or with water in which herbs that are appropriate have been boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The administration of a wind instrument with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of its opening be that of two spread fingers, as we have established: and let its depth be half a palm: and at the side, near the middle, there should be a small hole, according to the size through which a needle can enter: it should be made of brass or citron, with thick, smooth, even edges, so that it does not injure the limb when placed upon it: and in its middle there should be a transverse bar of brass or iron, where a candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this wind instrument is made large, larger than what we have described, and slightly smaller according to the ailments and age of the person who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the wind instruments for children and those who are thin are different from those for men and those with larger bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of placing this wind instrument with fire upon a limb is to light licinium with fire from flax appropriately, or a small candle from tallow: and place it above the middle transverse bar which is in the center of the wind instrument: so that the flame burns around the lower part of the wind instrument, so that the body of the sick person does not get burned.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then place it on the limb: and a finger should cover the hole I mentioned while we hold the wind instrument: when needed, remove the finger, and vapor will come out through that hole, causing the wind instrument to release immediately.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then light the flax with fire according to its method, and repeat this if you need it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In the wind instrument that is administered for pleurisy with water, there is no transverse bar nor hole: and it is not used except when filled with water and placed upon the limb.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And the larger the cupping vessel is, so that it can hold more water, the better it is.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	§ On the Suspension of Bloodletting Instruments.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter XCIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Bloodletting instruments are not used in many places unless it is in those parts of the body where cupping vessels cannot be placed due to their small size, such as the lip, gums, and similar areas.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or in parts of the body that are devoid of flesh, such as the fingers, nose, and similar areas.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is such that they should be taken from leeches found in fresh, clean water, free from decay.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they should be placed in fresh water day and night until they are hungry, and there is nothing left in their stomachs.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body should be cleansed initially with bloodletting and cupping.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then clean the affected limb until it becomes red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Then place them on the affected area.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are full and fall off, and it is possible to use cupping vessels on the area, then it is most beneficial for treatment; if not, then wash the area with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then wash it extensively with water, rub it, and press it.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the flow of blood continues after the leeches have fallen off and it is oozing, then soak a linen cloth in cold water, place it on top, until the oozing stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood multiplies, then powder zegi trituratum, or gall nuts, and similar astringents should be applied until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or apply half-cooked shelled beans to the place, and leave them until the beans adhere to the site, for then the blood will be stopped.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And if it is necessary to repeat the application of poultices, when possible, they should be changed.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If leeches refuse to attach due to the lack of blood flow, then the area should be wiped with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or pierce the area with an acupuncture needle until some blood flows out.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then apply the leeches, for when they sense blood, they will adhere immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When you want them to fall off, sprinkle powdered aloes, salt, or ashes on them, and they will fall off immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	¶ End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	¶ The Third Part of Albucasis' Book on Surgery.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	¶ A General Discussion on the Restoration, Dislocation, and Treatment of Sprains, and Similar Conditions.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is also often necessary in the art of Medicine and deals with the restoration of fractures and dislocations of bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know this, my children, for there are foolish physicians and the common folk who speak ignorantly about this chapter, and who have never inspected any ancient book nor read from it a single letter.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And for this reason it happens that this method is private among the sciences in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never fully succeeded in it without obstacles, and I did not attain from it what I attained except because of the length of reading ancient books and studying to understand them, until I extracted that science from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then I adhered to experimentation and study throughout the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you from that in this Chapter all that my science contains: and beyond what has been covered by my experience, after abbreviating it for you, and liberating it from the occupation of elongation, and abbreviating it with the end of abbreviation, and showing it with the end of declination: and I have formed many shapes in it from the forms of instruments that are used in it, since it is an addition to declination, as I did in two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Summary and collections concerning fractures of bones, from those whose preliminary information is necessary before we begin the recollection of fractured members and their various types.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary to say in the prologue of this Chapter the main points and sections, understanding which primarily the craftsman must strive for a station above their truth: namely, so that you and those who are quick may know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say then that when someone suffers a fracture, dislocation, torsion, or fall, it is necessary first to hurry to bleed them and relieve them, or both at the same time: unless something prohibits it, such as weakness of strength: or if the one who suffered from any of these is either a child or an elderly weak person: or if the time is extremely hot or extremely cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then let him be content with his food, with cold spices, and meat of birds and goats: and forbid wine, and fatty meats, and all foods that fill the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until he is free from the risk of a hot abscess and does not fear that its contents may spread to another part of the body, then let the patient return to his original diet with which he was accustomed to live.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When the healing of a fractured bone begins, then it is necessary that the patient be fed nourishing foods that are rich and heavy, with much viscosity: such as porridge made from boiled wheat with water, rice, head parts, feet, udders of cows, eggs, fresh fish: and thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	For with this regimen, the healing of the fracture occurs more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that bones that are fractured in those who are in the first stage of old age and are weak will not always be able to heal and strengthen according to their nature due to the drying of their limbs: but they will heal and join together at the point where they are least tense, like the bones of very young children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.
